title: Blood collection tubes
detail: [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image12.png]]

title: Blood rocker
detail:
• Blue, green, and purple top tubes contain anticoagulants and therefore should be rocked gently in the rocker until they can be read
• Red top tubes should be left in a rack to clot; they should not be rocked to prevent coagulation

title: CBC
detail:
• Gives information about RBCs, WBCs, and platelets
• Information about RBCs include PCV (hematocrit) results and hemoglobin, as well as RBC size and appearance
• Information about WBCs include number of WBCs and numbers of each type of WBC, as well as noting of leukocyte appearance
• Information about platelets include platelet count, size, and appearance
• Counting the reticulocytes requires new methylene blue, which will result in an RBC's absorbing stain so it’s not a part of CBC (can be done manually if indicated by the CBC)

title: PCV (aka hematocrit aka erythrocyte volume fraction)
detail:
• Proportion of RBCs to whole blood volume; percentage of volume of whole blood that consists of RBCs
• Normal is between 35-45% in dogs, 25-45% in cats
• Abnormally low reading indicates anemia
• An increased reading indicates dehydration or increase in RBC production
• Difference bw PCV and hematocrit is that PCV is manually determined, and hematocrit is calculated by machine—should be w/in 3-5% of each other
• Hematocrit concentration can be found by multiplying hemoglobin by 3
• If Hb is 5, HCT is 15%

title: Performing a PCV
detail:
• Need two microhematocrit tubes, a clay stopper, a PCV analyzer card, a microhematocrit centrifuge, and a microscope
• In addition to PCV, color pigmentation and clearness of plasma should be noted
• Sample can also be used to identify microfilaria and other blood-borne parasitic infestations by microscopic examination of the buffy coat and plasma fractions

title: Buffy coat
detail:
• Middle WBC layer between the whole blood and the plasma after centrifuging
• Consists of WBC overlaid by a thin layer of platelets
• If WBCs and/or platelets are elevated, a larger, white layer will be visible on top of the RBC column

title: Mean corpuscular volume
detail:
• Average volume of RBCs in the sample
• Measured in femtoliters (fL)—10-15
MCV = PCV x 1,000
RBC

title: Unopette system
detail:
• Calibration of the blood sample by diluting w acetic acid at a ratio of 1:100 before an RBC count
• Done for both manual and automated counts
• Reduces the number of cells to be counted

title: Hemoglobin
detail:
• Iron-containing protein that carries oxygen
• Assists in acid-base balance of blood
• Can be measured w photometric methods or automated counters
• Recorded as g/dL or g/L
• Roughly 1/3 of PCV

title: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (mean cell hemoglobin)
detail:
• Average mass of hemoglobin found in a sample per RBC
• Not as precise as PCV
• Measured in picograms (pg)—10-12
MCH = Hb concentration x 10
RBC

title: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
detail:
• Average concentration of hemoglobin in a given volume of packed RBCs
MCHC (g/L) = Hb concentration (g/L)
PCV
• Also indicates average shade of red for RBCs—lower value indicates paler cells
• Very precise

title: Abbreviated means and their indications
detail:
• MCV (mean cell/corpuscular volume) indicates cell size
• MCH (mean cell hemoglobin) is the quantity of hemoglobin in an average erythrocyte
• MCHC (mean cell hemoglobin concentration) is an expression of the average concentration of hemoglobin per average erythrocyte
• MPV (mean platelet volume) is the average size of circulating platelets

title: Preparing for blood smear
detail:
• Draw 2 mL of blood, place in EDTA purple-top tube
• Supplies needed are two glass slides w a frosted edge, microscope, immersion oil, and sample
• One slide is used at a 45-degree angle to spread the drop of blood placed on the other slide, forming a feathered edge
• Blood is evaluated once air-dried, fixed, and stained

title: Evaluation of a blood smear
detail:
• Smear (the monolayer) is examined under 100x magnification w immersion oil
• Three portions are evaluated for:
• RBC morphology—size, shape, color, and inclusions like Heinz bodies or Howell-Jolly bodies),
• WBC differential count—number of each type of cell in 100 WBCs and absolute value of each WBC type (i.e. number of cell type x total WBC count)
WBC differential should be interpreted based on absolute numbers of each cell type
• Estimated platelet count—total number of platelets in 10 fields ÷ 10 x 20,000 to get the estimated platelet number per microliter of blood

title: RBCs (erythrocytes)
detail:
• Carry oxygen by way of the protein hemoglobin
• As RBCs mature, they lose their nucleus, lose organelles, shrink in size, and gain hemoglobin
• Sizes differ in species
• No cell nucleus in mammals, but reptiles, birds, amphibians have nucleated RBCs
• Indices identify anemias and blood deficiencies
• Indices are established by RBC counts, hemoglobin content, and PCV (hematocrit)
• Number of RBCs can be counted w a hemacytometer (manual counter) or w automated counters
• Total RBC and platelet counts cannot be done manually with adequate accuracy

title: RBC sizes
detail:
• Normocytic: Average, uniform size of well-developed, mature erythrocytes
• Macrocytic: Unusually large RBCs
• Microcytic: Smaller than average RBCs; can be caused by vitamin or mineral deficiencies, genetic traits, some iatrogenic conditions
• Associated w decreased mean corpuscular volume and mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
• Hypochromic (paler than normal)
• Anisocytosis: Substantial discrepancies in RBC size; common in bovine blood; can be caused by responsive anemia in others
• Results noted as mild, moderate, or marked to indicate severity

title: RBC colors
detail:
• Normochromic: Fully developed RBCs w normal amount of hemoglobin; turn pinkish when stained, but has a whitish innermost area due to biconcave shape and lack of nucleus and organelles
• Polychromatic: RBCs w bluish tint (including lavender) due to staining of organelles (so young cells—possibly due to responsive anemia); usually also macrocytic
• Hypochromic: Cells w inadequate hemoglobin concentration; much paler pink when stained, and have an increased central pallor
• Hyperchromatic: Increase color intensity; appear more darkly stained, as if oversaturated w hemoglobin (this can’t occur bc RBC has a fixed max capacity); usually microcytes or spherocytes
• Torocyte: RBC w an abrupt transition from pale center to red hemoglobin-rich sides; aka punched-out cell, typically induced by poor slide smear

title: RBC abnormalities
detail:
• Poikilocytosis
• Codocytes
• Leptocytes
• Ovalocytes (elliptocytes)
• Schistocytes
• Spherocytes
• Stomatocytes
• Spiculated erythrocytes
• Acanthocytes
• Echinocytes

title: Poikilocytosis
detail:
• 10% or more increase in the number of abnormally shaped RBCs
• Variation in RBC shape

title: Codocytes (target cells)
detail:
• RBCs that have undergone a surface volume change resulting in excess cell membrane
• Called target cells due to dark circular target appearance (multiple rings of light and dark colors)
• Indicative of liver disease; may be due to membrane collapse secondary to very low hemoglobin content, increased cholesterol and lecithin content, bile insufficiency, liver disease, splenectomy, anemia

title: Leptocytes
detail:
• RBCs that have undergone a surface volume change resulting in excess cell membrane, resulting in abnormally thin, flattened RBCs
• Aka Mexican hat cells due to central rounded area of pigmented material, unpigmented mid-zone, and outer pigmented rim
• May be due to a reduction in hemoglobin volume or increase in the surface are of cell membrane; occurs in regenerative anemia

title: Ovalocytes (elliptocytes)
detail:
• Cigar or egg-shaped RBCs w normal light/pale center color
• May be due to a flaw in the membrane

title: Schistocytes
detail:
• Fragmented RBCs of varying shapes including horn-like keratocytes, triangular triangulocytes, helmet-shaped cells
• Fragmentation usually occurs due to RBCs being cut by fibrin strands lining micro-vessels
• Similar to Heinz bodies, but those are softer-edged “bite” cells that occur when spleen ingests abnormal hemoglobin leaving a bitten-apple appearance
• Seen in burns, uremia, some hemolytic anemias, disseminated intravascular coagulation disorders

title: Spherocytes
detail:
• RBCs w a round, spherical form instead of the biconcave disk shape
• Indicative of hemolytic anemia, but may be caused by defective membrane assembly, traumatic/toxic injury
• Diameter is 2/3 of a normal RBC w a smaller surface area
• Hemoglobin is denser, stains a deeper red
• Lacks a central pallor
• More readily seen in dogs bc many other animals have smaller RBCs w less central pallor (e.g. cats, horses)
• Important to focus on monolayer bc normal RBCs can look like spherocytes in thick areas of a dog’s blood smear

title: Stomatocytes
detail:
• Have an abnormal-appearing, rod-shape or smile-shaped center
• May be caused in dogs due to an inherited disorder or due to liver disease

title: Spiculated erythrocytes
detail:
• Acanthocytes (spur cells): Cells w obvious blunt protrusions/spikes; inconsistently shaped
• Occurs due to excess cholesterol in cell membrane bc of high blood cholesterol and/or abnormal plasma lipoproteins
• Echinocytes (burr cells): Cells w micro-spikes protruding from a roughly spherical surface
• Found in animals w renal disease, in horses after vigorous exercise, and in dogs w lymphosarcoma; also seen in uremia, liver disease, low potassium or ATP in RBCs, hypomagnesemia, hypophosphatemia, high calcium in RBCs, absence of spleen, hyperlipidemia, heparin therapy
• May indicate handling errors

title: Agglutination
detail:
• RBCs clustered together
• Has a grainy appearance on the slide
• Automated counting doesn’t work
• Can be caused by presence of an antibody, or immune disease

title: Basophilic stippling
detail:
• Presence of small, dark-blue bodies within the erythrocyte
• Represent residual RNA
• Observed using new methylene blue stain—RNA will be tiny, blue granules inside RBCs
• Results from ineffective heme formation due to some anemias or lead poisoning
• Also a characteristic of active erythropoiesis in sheep and cattle

title: Blister cell (aka pyknocyte or hemighost)
detail:
• RBC w a blister
• No hemoglobin content
• Commonly a result of oxidation damage, potentially due to iron deficiency anemia
• Spleen may remove the blister, or it may rupture, leading to a keratocyte (horn cell)
• Sometimes the cell may form one, slim protrusion, then called an apple stem cell

title: Crenation
detail:
• Contraction of RBCs due to lack of water
• Notched or scalloped edges are characteristic
• Seen when RBCs dry on the smear

title: Eccentrocytes
detail:
• RBCs that have been subject to oxidation, resulting in cell adhesion of cell membranes from opposing sides of the cell
• Hemoglobin forced to one side of the cell gives the appearance of semi-circular form
• Associated w fragmented anemia, keratocytes, schistocytes
• Can be caused by onion and garlic ingestion, and antioxidant drugs

title: Ghost cells
detail:
• RBCs that have lysed in a hypotonic solution spilling out their hemoglobin contents
• Still has the normal disk shape, and some hemoglobin remains, so looks very pale pink once stained

title: Howell-Jolly bodies
detail:
• RBCs that didn’t entirely expel their nuclear DNA, which is visible as purple-blue basophilic, circular inclusions upon staining
• Basophilic (blue-staining) nuclear remnants seen in young erythrocytes during response to anemia
• Indicative of markedly decreased splenic function; associated w splenectomy, regenerative anemia, spleen disorders
• Most cats and horses have 1% of their RBCs as Howell-Jolly bodies

title: Heinz (Ehrlich) bodies
detail:
• Small inclusions of denatured hemoglobin found in RBCs
• Viewed w Wright’s or Diff-Quick stains, as well as new methylene blue
• Associated w toxic reactions, onion consumption, some oxidant drugs, lymphosarcoma, and hyperthyroidism
• Frequent in cats, but abrupt increase in number may indicate DM

title: nRBCs
detail:
• Younger, smaller RBCs that have retained their nucleus
• Nucleus stains dark, cytoplasm is bluish-red
• Significant if more than 5 in a 100 WBC count
• Normally N/A in mammalian peripheral blood films; indicates serious bone marrow stress (e.g. hemolytic anemia, metastatic cancer)—represent early release of immature cells during anemia
• Increased numbers indicate hyperproduction of RBCs, not allowing them to mature before releasing into the bloodstream
• Normal in some species like birds, reptiles, fish, amphibians, which have well developed elliptical nRBCs

title: Rouleaux
detail:
• RBCs gathered in chains or stacks
• Cells aren’t free to absorb and carry oxygen
• Precursor to many serious diseases
• Indicates inflammation and pathology in dogs
• Considered normal in horses, somewhat normal in cats and pigs (concerning if in large numbers)
• Should be differentiated from agglutination, which is 3D clumping of variably sized RBCs, and would indicate IMHA in dogs

title: Reticulocytes
detail:
• Immature RBCs
• Contain organelles (ribosomes) that are lost as the cell matures; nonnucleated
• Visible only when stained
• Reticulocytes on a modified Wright stain (e.g., Diff-Quik) appear polychromatic—Wright’s stain gives bluish-gray color indicating presence of cytoplasmic RNA
• New methylene blue makes ribosomal DNA directly visible, enabling easy counting of reticulocytes

title: Reticulocyte production index (corrected reticulocyte count)
detail:
• Determines how rapidly reticulocytes are released into the bloodstream
• Reticulocytes should constitute less than 1% of RBCs in most animals
• Blood loss, RBC life shortened by disease, general anemia, low oxygen intake can cause increase in reticulocyte numbers (i.e. reticulocytosis)
• In case of anemia, because RBC count is low, reticulocyte percentage will be artificially high—this is corrected by RPI or corrected reticulocyte count
RPI = Reticulocyte Count x (Hematocrit ÷
Normal Hematocrit (i.e. 35 to 40))
• If RPI is 100,000 mm3 or higher, anemia is likely hyperproliferative (hemolytic or from blood loss); if below that anemia is likelu hypoproliferative (iron, B12, or folic deficiency, suppressed bone marrow)
• Horses only discharge reticulocytes into circulation directly from bone marrow in case of severe chronic anemia, so the assessment isn’t used for horses

title: Cat reticulocytes
detail:
• Cats have two forms of reticulocytes
• Aggregate form contains large clumps of reticulum; similar to reticulocytes in other species
• Punctate form is unique to cats; contains two to eight small, singular, basophilic granules
• Only aggregate form is counted in reticulocyte count

title: Staining for anemia
detail: • Reticulocytes are evaluated when assessing anemia, so counts are performed using a blood film stained with new methylene blue

title: RBCs in other species
detail:
• In llamas, RBCs are the predominant cell type; hemoglobin pigment may appear evenly disbursed throughout the cell or concentrated at each end of the oval, lacking a central pallor
• Bird and reptile erythrocytes are oval and nucleated
• Horse erythrocytes are round and anucleated

title: Leukocytes (WBCs)
detail:
• Neutrophils: First responders—primary function is phagocytosis; continue to be present at the site as long as inflammation lasts; engulf microorganisms to destroy them, and signal other WBCs to the site (most common)
• Eosinophils: Associated w mast cells, allergies, parasitic disease, fungal infections; larger than neutrophils and have segmented nuclei w eosinophilic cytoplasmic granules; cytoplasm stains red-purple
• Lymphocytes: T and B cells that arrive a few days after inflammation starts; round nuclei of the size of an RBC (most common)
• Monocytes: Phagocytic cells; when they migrate to tissues they mature and become macrophages; they remove damaged cells and microorganisms; found in peripheral blood; stains gray-blue cytoplasm (largest); have lobular nuclei
• Basophils: Scarce normally, but increase due to allergic or parasitic response; never found in peripheral blood; cytoplasm stains blue or blue-black

title: Eosinophils
detail:
• WBC w primary function of modulation of the immune system
• Associated w mast cells, allergies, parasitic disease, fungal infections
• Have segmented nuclei w eosinophilic cytoplasmic granules
• Feline eosinophilic granules are rod shaped and small; dog, horse, and cow eosinophils have round to globoid granules
• Increased numbers of eosinophils are common in patients w allergic reactions and parasite infections or infestations

title: [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image05.png]]
detail: [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image27.png]]

title: Observing stained leukocytes
detail:
• Observed at the monolayer
• Feathered edge not useful (WBC shapes distorted)

title: Groups of leukocytes
detail:
• Polymorphnuclear: Aka granulocytes—stain reveals granules in the cytoplasm; include neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils
• Mononuclear: Nongranular; include monocytes, lymphocytes

title: Left shift
detail:
• Increase number of immature neutrophils (band cells)
• Degenerative left shift occurs when the number of immature neutrophils exceeds the number of mature neutrophils and the total WBC is decreasing
• Regenerative left shift occurs when the number of mature neutrophils exceeds the number of immature neutrophils and the total WBC is normal to increasing

title: Leukocytosis
detail: • Increased number of leukocytes

title: Band cells
detail:
• Band neutrophils—immature neutrophils
• Has a horseshoe- or S-shaped nucleus

title: Lymphocytes
detail:
• B cells (plasma cells) produce antibodies (humoral immunity)
• T cells manage immune responses and kill infected cells (cell-mediated immunity)
• NK cells (innate immunity) target virus-infected or cancerous cells without prior sensitization

title: WBC abnormalities
detail:
• Nuclear hyposegmentation (congenital Pelger-Huet anomaly)—all granulocyte nuclei
• Nuclear hypersegmentation (attributable to aging)—neutrophils
• Normal neutrophils contain 3-4 nuclear lobes; hypersegmented neutrophils contain six or more
• Toxic change in neutrophils
• Common in cats, not in dogs; indicate bacterial infection when severe
• Include cytoplasmic basophilia, Dohle bodies (dark granules), vacuoles or foaminess, and toxic granulation (rare)

title: Neutrophil nucleus
detail:
• Mammalian neutrophils have 3-5 nuclear lobes
• Number of segments increases as it matures, after being released into the blood from the bone marrow
• Hypersegmented neutrophils contain six or more lobes

title: Platelets (thrombocytes)
detail:
• Disc-shaped fragments of megakaryocytes that assist w blood clotting
• Production involves the thrombopoietin hormone (produced in the liver, but also in kidney) and additional cytokines
• Appear smaller than RBCs, except in cats

title: Thrombocytopenia vs. thrombocytosis
detail:
• Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count; causes bleeding due to lack of adequate numbers of platelets to form a platelet plug
• Leads to petechiae, ecchymoses, and anemia
• Thrombocytosis: Elevated number of platelets

title: Thrombopathia
detail: • Abnormal platelet function

title: EDTA
detail:
• Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid
• Coagulant of choice for CBC because it preserves cellular components, cell morphology and prevents platelet aggregation
• Available as sodium or potassium salt; prevents clotting by forming an insoluble complex with calcium, which is necessary for clot formation
• Must be inverted multiple times
• Must be kept refrigerated

title: Hematology tests Complete Blood Count (CBC) RBC count Hemoglobin (Hgb) Hematocrit / PCV WBC count Platelet count RBC Indices (used to classify anemia) MCV – mean cell volume (cell size) MCHC – mean cell hemoglobin concentration RDW – red cell size variation (anisocytosis) WBC Differential (evaluates immune response) Includes each WBC and assessment of left shift, toxic changes, leukocytosis/leukopenia Platelet Evaluation (assesses clotting potential) Platelet count Platelet estimate on smear Detection of clumping or giant platelets
detail:
• Blood Smear Evaluation
• RBC morphology (anisocytosis, poikilocytosis)
• WBC morphology
• Platelet adequacy
• Blood parasites (e.g., Babesia, Mycoplasma)
• Reticulocyte Count (evaluates bone marrow response)
• Packed Cell Volume (PCV)
• Total Protein (TP) (helps interpret anemia and dehydration)
Specialized / Situational Hematology Tests
• Coagulation Testing
• PT
• aPTT
• ACT
• Bleeding time
• Bone Marrow Evaluation
• Buffy Coat Examination

title: Coagulation testing
detail:
• Blood should be collected into a blue-top tube; contains sodium citrate
• Blood is centrifuged for 5 minutes, then plasma is removed and transferred to a clean tube w/out anticoagulant and kept frozen until analysis

title: Sending out blood samples
detail:
• Samples should be labeled w patient name, client name, date, clinic name, test to be run
• Corresponding form from the lab should include the same information plus the age, sex, and N/S status of patient, as well as doctor name and whether patient has been fasted

title: Storing hematology samples
detail:
• CBC samples that are not tested within 1 hour should be refrigerated for cell preservation, and warmed to room temperature before analysis
• Hematology samples, including plasma, serum, and whole blood, should be refrigerated until sent out to the lab; delivery should be made w ice packs
• Coagulation testing samples should be kept in the freezer or sent out w/in half an hour
• Serum can be frozen for chemistry testing (some tests require serum to be frozen)

title: Hemolysis
detail:
• Rupture and destruction of RBCs
• Usually due to improper specimen collection such as contamination, incorrect tube mixing or filling, incorrect needle size

title: Hemolysin
detail: • Type of bacterial toxin (exotoxin) that destroys RBCspl

title: Plasma
detail:
• Yellowish fluid that contains the blood, proteins, and lipid particles in the bloodstream
• Makes up of 55% of total blood volume
• Made up of water (90%), and dissolved proteins, hormones, lipids, enzymes, salts, carbohydrates, vitamins, and waste
• WBCs, RBCs, platelets are suspended in plasma
• Anticoagulants can be added to plasma to prevent clotting
• To obtain plasma sample, 3 mL of blood is placed in a green-top heparinized tube

title: Anticoagulants
detail:
• Heparin is preferred for plasma samples due to low propensity to alter the chemical analysis [MOA: antithrombin]
• EDTA is preferred for hematologic studies (like CBC) bc it doesn’t alter cell morphology [MOA: chelates calcium]
• Citrate (sodium or lithium) is preferred for coagulation testing and transfusions [MOA: chelates calcium]
• Sodium citrates interfere w sodium assays, as well as many blood chemistry tests
• Oxalate (potassium, sodium, lithium) is preferred for coagulation testing [MOA: chelates calcium]
• Potassium oxalate can’t be used w blood samples to be assayed for potassium
• Fluorides (sodium) is preferred to preserve blood glucose [MOA: chelates calcium] but interferes w many enzyme tests

title: Serum
detail:
• Plasma after coagulation has occurred; post-clotted liquid part of blood
• Centrifugation removes clotted and solid materials
• To obtain serum sample, 3 mL of blood is placed in a serum separator tube, allowed to clot, then spun in a centrifuge, drawn off the sample w/in an hour, and placed in a red-top tube
• Prolonged exposure of serum to the blood cells before the serum is removed from the clot can result in increased phosphorus as phosphorus starts leaking out of the cells

title: Plasma vs. serum
detail:
• Serum what is left over from plasma after clotting
• Meaning plasma has fibrinogen and serum does not
• Fibrinogen is a protein, so plasma will have higher protein levels that serum
• Both serum and plasma can be used to measure electrolytes
• Plasma and serum have the same color

title: Serum abnormalities
detail:
• Hemolytic serum: Pink/reddish; indicates rupture of RBCs; tests performed on hemolytic serum may show higher levels of phosphorus, potassium, total protein, and aspartate aminotransferase
• Icteric serum (jaundice): Yellowish; indicates liver disease, bile obstruction, or excessive hemolysis as in hemolytic anemia; tests tend to show high bilirubin readings
• Lipemic serum: Murky, opaque, milky; high concentration of suspended fat; indicates high triglyceride or lipid levels due to poor diet; may cause inaccurate chemical analysis in some tests; fasting at least 12 hours will get better results (animals who recently ate may give lipemic samples)

title: Separating serum from blood sample
detail:
• Sample must reach room temp
• Blood should be left to clot for 20-30 min
• A wooden stick is used to separate clot from sides of the tube
• Sample is centrifuged for 10 min at 2,000-3,000 rpm (prolonged centrifugation can cause hemolysis)
• Serum at the top of the tube is poured into another tube (a pipette can be used)

title: Total serum protein
detail:
• Calculated based on the amount of albumin and globulin, the two primary proteins in the blood at a ratio close to 1:1
• Gauged w a Goldberg refractometer, or
• Measured using the Biuret method (automated or computer analyzer applies a total dye binding process to calculate serum proteins)
• Heparin or EDTA can be used to collect samples (heparin results will be a little lower)
• Sample shouldn’t be lipemic or hemolyzed

title: Total serum protein variations
detail:
• Globulin levels tend to rise as albumin levels lower, meaning total serum protein will usually stay the same
• Changes to total serum protein may be induced by shock
• High albumin levels may be due to severe dehydration
• Low albumin levels may be due to malnutrition, severe burns, some kidney and liver diseases, GI malabsorption, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, uncontrolled diabetes, hyperthyroidism, heart failure
• Decreased albumin can be seen in liver failure but is not usually seen in chronic liver disease
• High globulin levels may be due to blood diseases, autoimmune diseases, some kidney or liver diseases

title: Serum albumin
detail:
• Albumin is the most abundant plasma protein; produced by the liver
• Mainly responsible for maintaining colloidal oncotic pressure in the vascular space; also transports substances such as hormones, drugs, and electrolytes in the blood
• Shock may increase albumin levels
• Acute liver disease, starvation, undernourishment, malabsorption, enteritis, colitis, parasites, pregnancy, lactation, persistent fever, uncontrolled diabetes, shock, nephritis, ascites, blood loss/reduction may lower levels
• Serum albumin levels can be calculated using the albumin dye binding technique

title: Globulin
detail:
• Proteins mostly involved in the immune defense system
• Level is determined by subtracting albumin from total protein
• Antigenic stimulation, inflammation, infection, neoplasia, or abnormal immunoglobin production can increase levels

title: Protein electrophoresis
detail:
• Specialized test that analyzes how much of each group of protein is present in the blood serum based on distinctive sizes and electrical charges
• Performed on serum
• Results are displayed on a special graph, and the pattern of the different proteins is used to help diagnose specific diseases

title: Urea (carbamide)
detail:
• Urea is byproduct of protein breakdown
• Liver converts ammonia to nontoxic urea; in mammals, nitrogen waste is excreted as urea (carbamide)
• Helps produce countercurrent system in kidneys—as some urea is reabsorbed, osmolarity raises in the kidneys, leading to reabsorption of more water and essential ions—this leads to BP maintenance and proper plasma sodium concentration
• 40% of the urea is ideally reabsorbed by the tubules, remainder is excreted in urine and sweat—kidneys excrete urea and ≤40% is reabsorbed by the tubules for re-excretion
• Rate of reabsorption is inversely proportional to the amount of urine output, so excreted urea is a measure of health of the glomerular filtration system (urea evaluates both filtration and function)

title: Urea nitrogen (serum urea nitrogen)
detail:
• Plasma samples w heparin or EDTA used to measure UN
• Samples are taken w ammonium oxalate, which artificially increases BUN levels (vs. samples taken w fluoride, which artificially lowers BUN levels
• Increased serum urea nitrogen may be due to dehydration, heart failure, increase in protein consumption, corticosteroids, fever, as well as renal issues
• High-protein diets and strenuous exercise may cause an elevated BUN due to increased amino acid breakdown
• Lower levels of urea excretion are expected in anorexia, liver disease, renal tubular damage

title: BUN
detail:
• Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is a laboratory test that evaluates kidney function
• A breakdown product of protein that healthy, functioning kidneys remove

title: Serum creatinine
detail:
• Creatinine is produced as a result of normal muscle metabolism—creatine phosphate is found in muscles and brain; it anaerobically generates ATP from ADP in cases of intense energy demands or low oxygen, producing creatinine as a byproduct (Normally, ATP will breakdown into ADP using oxygen, and energy will be released)
• Creatinine is an indicator of GFR—glomeruli in kidneys filter almost all creatinine out of the blood, so high serum creatinine indicates low or non-functioning glomeruli
• High creatinine may also mean dehydration or renal issues
• Usually evaluated in conjunction w BUN and urine SG
• Hemolytic serums and hyperbilirubinemia can lead to misleading results

title: Serum alanine aminotransferase (serum glutamic pyruvate transaminase) (alanine transaminase)
detail:
• Enzymes of liver and muscle tissue, which are released into the bloodstream if either is injured
• More than 90% of ALT/SGPT are found in hepatocytes in dogs, cats, rats, rabbits, and primates—so, elevated ALT levels usually indicate liver disease in these species
• ALT/SGPT is more active in muscle tissue in birds, horses, pigs, and ruminants—so, elevated levels indicate muscle injury or necrosis
• Measured in plasma or serum samples
• Decreased levels bw two tests may indicate transient injury
• Consistent high levels indicate serious disease
• Meds may cause changes in dogs, but unlikely in cats

title: Serum alkaline phosphatase
detail:
• Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is an enzyme that catalyzes phosphoric acid and participates in construction of all body tissues
• Produced mostly in the liver and the bone, and some in intestines and kidneys (also by placenta during pregnancy)
• Usually low levels in serum
• Elevated ALP (usually due to extra production of ALP by tissues) may indicate intrahepatic or post-hepatic cholestasis, med-induced liver damage, bone tumor, osteomalacia, parathyroid hormone overproduction
• Corticosteroids and anticonvulsants will increase levels for 2 weeks
• Elevated levels in the young may be normal due to bone growth, but in older animals indicates bone injury or liver disease

title: Serum gamma-glutamyl transferase
detail:
• GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, pancreas, kidney
• High serum levels indicate liver dysfunction, especially cholestasis and fatty liver, as well as some meds
• High ALT and GGT levels together are cause for exploration of liver disease in small animals

title: Serum aspartate aminotransferase (formerly serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase)
detail:
• Enzyme linked to cardiac muscle, diaphragmatic muscle, skeletal muscle, liver
• Increased AST levels expected in case of injury to any of the tissues above
• Can be measured in serum or plasma
• Hemolyzed or lipemic samples may be misleading
• Should be read w ALT tests; results of AST alone are not definitive

title: Serum sodium
detail:
• Sodium is essential to sustaining osmotic pressure and fluid balance; key to extracellular positive ion attraction that primes the sodium-potassium-ATPase pump
• Hypernatremia may be caused by dehydration
• Hyponatremia may be due to kidney failure, V/D in ass w diuretics, disproportionate ADH, CHF, water toxicity
• Serum sample should not be hemolyzed
• Plasma samples can be used if lithium or ammonium heparin is used
• Both serum and plasma samples must be centrifuged to remove cellular components from fluid

title: Serum potassium
detail:
• Potassium is a cation (positive ion) that sustains fluid and electrolyte balance
• Normal range in serum and plasma is 3.5 to 5.5. mEq/L
• Hyperkalemia may be due to adrenal cortical hypofunction, acidosis, late-stage renal failure
• Hyperkalemia is commonly associated w hypoadrenocorticism
• Hypokalemia may be due to alkalosis, insulin therapy, fluid loss ass w diuretics or V/D
• Plasma samples give better results; should be heparinized
• Blood cells must be separated w/in 2 hours to avoid alteration of results; especially true for horses and cattle bc their cells release potassium over time

title: Serum chloride
detail:
• Levels are controlled by kidneys
• Hyperchloremia may be due to metabolic acidosis, renal tubular acidosis, overactive parathyroid glands
• Hypochloremia may be due to vomiting, anorexia, malnutrition, diabetes insipidus

title: Serum calcium
detail:
• 99% of calcium is found w/in bones, the rest helps move inorganic ions and fluids throughout the body
• Calcium is needed in cell membrane functions, blood coagulation, muscle contraction, nerve impulse transmission, and activation of some enzymes
• Calcium and phosphorus levels are controlled by parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, and vit D
• Serum calcium should be assessed along w serum protein and albumin levels
• Hypercalcemia may be due to pseudohyperparathyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, excessive vit D, cancerous bony metastases
• Hypocalcemia may be due to malabsorption, eclampsia, pancreatic necrosis, hypoalbuminemia, hypoparathyroidism
• Nonhemolyzed serum or heparinized plasma sample needed

title: Serum phosphorus
detail:
• 80% is in the skeleton
• Levels are regulated by parathyroid hormone (also calcium)
• Has an inverse relation w calcium levels, so should be monitored together
• Hyperphosphatemia may be due to kidney failure, anuria, hypoparathyroidism, excessive vit D, or ethylene glycol poisoning
• Hypophosphatemia may be due to diet low in phosphorus, primary hyperparathyroidism, malabsorption, hyperinsulinism, D, lymphosarcoma, hyperadrenocorticism
• Non-hemolyzed serum or heparinized plasma needed

title: Blood glucose
detail:
• Insulin is responsible for moving glucose out of the blood and into the cells to be burned for energy
• Insulin, glucagon, and somatostatin are secreted by pancreas
• Hyperglycemia indicates DM—pancreas produces insufficient insulin, leading to high levels of blood glucose
• Stress-induced hyperglycemia possible in cats
• Prolonged contact of serum with RBCs will cause a false decrease in glucose bc RBCs will continue to consume glucose after collection
• Dogs and cats should be fasted 16 to 24 hours
• Ruminants don’t need to be fasted
• Serum is preferred, but will test at 5% higher glucose level

title: Bilirubin
detail:
• Byproduct of hemoglobin metabolism—hemoglobin is broken down to heme and globin by the mononuclear phagocytic system, heme is then broken into bilirubin and liver modifies it (and other byproducts) so it can be excreted
• Bilirubin not yet modified is unconjugated/indirect bilirubin; conjugated/direct bilirubin is attached to a glucuronide (creating glucuronic acid) to be excreted in bile—total number of two is taken
• Hyperbilirubinemia occurs if bilirubin is built up faster than can be metabolized by the liver; too high can make skin, mucus membranes, whites of eyes yellow (jaundice)
• When levels are high, bilirubin may be excreted in urine instead of bile, passing thru bile ducts into intestines where direct bilirubin will be broken down by bacteria to urobilinogen, which gives stool its normal yellowish-brown color
• Unconjugated bilirubin isn’t water soluble, so not found in urine
• Small amounts of bilirubin are normal in dogs bc renal threshold for bilirubin is low

title: Serum cholesterol
detail:
• Cholesterol is a steroid alcohol created thru liver synthesis
• Hypothyroidism can result from high cholesterol levels; high levels may also indicate lipemia, DM, hyperadrenocorticism, nephrotic syndrome, certain liver diseases, bile duct obstruction, pregnancy complications
• Other diagnostics should be run to diagnose liver disease
• Fasting necessary to determine accurate base level
• Nonhemolyzed serum or heparinized plasma needed

title: Serum bile acid
detail:
• Bile is produced by the liver; synthesized from cholesterol; stored in the gall bladder (except in horses and rats)
• Significant role in digestive processes—since bile is hydrophobic and hydrophilic at the same time, it can break down water-insoluble fats in water-saturated environments like the intestines
• Low levels post-meal may indicate ileal dysfunction
• High levels indicate liver disease and hepatocytic inability to filter bile
• Paired serum samples are performed after 12 hours of fasting, and again 2 hours after animal eats—postprandial (after meal) serum bile acid concentrations are higher than fasting concentrations, and serum bile acid level is normally elevated after a meal because gallbladder has releases increased amounts of bile into the duodenum
• Test reports the difference between the prefasted and postprandial levels
• Inadequate fasting can increase fasting bile acid level
• In horses, one sample is needed since they don’t store bile in the gallbladder

title: Sorbitol dehydrogenase
detail:
• Enzyme produced in liver cells
• Effective indicator of acute hepatocellular damage
• Very sensitive to toxin, so early indicator of toxin- or drug-induced liver toxicity
• Necrosis in liver can lead to high levels
• Must be measured in large animals to diagnose liver disease—more appropriate than ALT testing
• Sample must be analyzed asap since SDH enzyme is unstable

title: Serum amylase
detail:
• Amylase is a digestive enzyme that breaks down carbohydrates and starches into sugars, first in saliva; also found in pancreas where it catabolizes glycogen into glucose
• Increase in levels may be due to acute, chronic, or obstructive pancreatitis, hyperadrenocorticism, upper GI inflammation, digestive system obstructions, kidney failure
• Serum should be diluted w a prescribed amount of normal saline to compensate for higher rate of amylase activity in animals compared to humans (test is originally for humans)
• Nonlipemic serum or heparinized plasma needed
• Hemolysis can cause artificially high results

title: Serum lipase
detail:
• Lipase is the enzyme that digests long-chain fatty acids that constitute lipids, producing reduced fatty acids and alcohols
• High levels may be due to acute or chronic pancreatitis, kidney failure, hyperadrenocorticism, dexamethasone treatment, bile tract disease
• Non-hemolyzed and non-lipemic serum or heparinized plasma needed

title: Serum trypsin-like immunoreactivity test
detail:
• Definitive test for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which causes a lack of digestive enzymes to properly digest food
• Measures blood levels of trypsin, trypsinogen
• Trypsin breaks down proteins; normally in the pancreas, only enters blood if pancreas is inflamed
• Trypsinogen forerunner enzyme found very little in blood
• 12-hour fasting necessary

title: Testing for Cushing’s
detail:
• A good initial urinary screening test for suspected Cushing's disease is cortisol/creatinine ratio; tests adrenal function
• Blood tests include endogenous ACTH, low-dose dexamethasone, and ACTH stimulation

title: ACTH stimulation test
detail:
• Used to detect Cushing’s
• Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is produced by the pituitary gland and signals adrenal glands how much cortisol to produce—as cortisol levels in the blood increase, pituitary gland decreases ACTH production
• The test consists of drawing a baseline blood cortisol, followed by an ACTH injection (IV), an hour after which a sample is taken to compare w the baseline
• A dog w Cushing’s will have increased cortisol production in the hour after since body isn’t being alerted to slow cortisol production

title: Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
detail:
• Used to diagnose Cushing’s in dogs
• The test consists of drawing a baseline blood cortisol, followed by a dexamethasone (synthetic cortisol) injection (IV), 4-8 hours after which a sample is taken to compare w the baseline—ACTH production should be lowered since cortisol levels in the blood increase w the injection
• LDSS test can tell if Cushing’s is pituitary or adrenal in origin—if there is a pituitary tumor, cortisol will slightly decrease in the 4-8 hours; if there is an adrenal tumor, there will be no reduction

title: Non-plasma specific enzyme testing
detail:
• Some enzyme should never be found in plasma/serum unless there is destruction of tissue cells, intensified tissue cell production, barriers in excretory paths, or poor circulation
• Test kit will include substrates, coenzymes, cofactors

title: Staining in clinical cytology
detail:
• 3 types of Romanowsky stains: Wright’s, Giemsa, Diff-Quik
• Staining quality differs from one product to the other, so single type should be used for consistency of interpretations
• Stains contain alcohol, which is highly flammable, so proper storage in a flammable safe cabinet and MSDS sheets necessary
• New methylene blue is used to examine nuclei, mast cell granules, and most infectious organisms
• Use only to examine nucleated cells, bacteria, fungi, mast cells
• Core bone marrow samples are evaluated w hematoxylin and eosin stain, while bone marrow aspirates are assessed using Romanowsky stains

title: Gram-negative and -positive bacteria
detail:
• Purple indicates gram-positive
• Gram-positive bacteria contain preformed exotoxins, which they secrete into the surrounding medium
• Pink indicates gram-negative
• Gram-negative bacteria contain endotoxins in their cell walls, whereas

title: Bacteria growth environments (pH)
detail:
• Most bacteria grow in a neutral pH (6.5–7.0)
• Some thrive in acidic environments with a pH as low as 1.0 (e.g. lactic acid bacteria—large group of bacteria)
• Very few that can thrive in alkaline environments (e.g. UTI-causing bacteria like Staphylococcus bacteria)

title: Catalase test
detail:
• Performed on gram-positive cocci and small gram-positive bacilli
• Tests for the enzyme catalase, which acts on hydrogen peroxide to produce water and oxygen
• A small amount of a colony from blood agar is placed on a slide and a drop of catalase reagent (3% hydrogen peroxide) is added—if the colony is catalase positive, gas bubbles are produced; no bubble production indicates a negative result
• Staphylococci is catalase-positive (can be used as control), streptococci is catalase-negative

title: Fine needle aspiration
detail:
• 25-gauge needle and 10 mL syringe
• Small amount of suction applied and needle redirected few times inside the mass while suctioning to get sample
• Suction should be released without pulling out
• Needle is removed, syringe is filled w air, and needle is replaced before pushing the plunger to express sample onto clean slide
• Too much pressure will rupture cells
• Sample is air dried and stained w modified Wright or rapid stain
• Examined under 40x, immersion oil and 40x, and immersion oil and 100x
• Highly cellular fluids can be smeared directly, but low-cellularity fluids should be centrifuged first to concentrate cells

title: Impression smears
detail:
• Can be used for cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues
• Surgically removed tissue can also be used
• A slide is touched to the cut surface (fluid/blood blotted clean)
• Best for epithelial cells, lymph nodes, splenic tissue, mast cell tumors, and other tissues that exfoliate cells easily

title: Scraping
detail:
• Can be used for tissues that don’t readily exfoliate cells
• A sterile scalpel blade is used to mildly scrape on a freshly cut tissue surface
• Scraping is streaked on the slide and air-dried before staining

title: Fluid aspiration
detail:
• Include abdominocentesis, thoracocentesis, cystocentesis, cerebrospinal fluid tap, arthrocentesis
• Surgical scrub necessary
• Fluid samples are examined for color, odor, turbidity (opaque qualities); total nucleated cell count and total protein should be noted
• Types of fluids include:
• Transudates (total protein less than 3 g/dL)
• Exudates
• Modified transudates (total protein count bw 2.5 and 7.4 g/dL w opaque or pink coloration—higher than 3 g/dL indicates inflammation)

title: Scope of urinalysis
detail: • A complete urinalysis has the following parts in the following order: (1) Gross examination; (2) Specific gravity; (3) Biochemical analysis; (4) Sediment examination

title: Urinalysis samples
detail:
• Samples should be analyzed w/in 30 min or refrigerated up to 24 hours
• Refrigeration acceptable for pH and specific gravity
• If urine cytology needs to wait, 10% formalin should be added
• Sample degradation may lead to rise in ammonia levels, hemolyzed RBCs, pH levels that allow bacterial growth, lower levels of bilirubin/glucose/ketones/WBCs/urobil, disappearance of casts, alteration in crystals, darker color, appearance of nitrites, harsher smell, change in protein concentration, muddy/opaque appearance
• Exposure of urine to UV light would result in the deterioration of bilirubin, leading to false negatives

title: Urine color
detail:
• Color is directly related to urochromes, which give the urine its yellow color
• Specific gravity is the ratio of urine density as compared w water; it is responsible for intensity of urine color
• Urine w low specific gravity will appear lighter
• Urine’s specific gravity will increase w dehydration
• Normal color is pale yellow to yellowish brown
• Urine containing bile will be more greenish and froth when shaken
• RBCs in urine will lead to reddish tint (hematuria)
• Hemoglobin in urine will cause a reddish-brown tint (hemoglobinuria)
• Brown-tint indicates myoglobinuria

title: Urine transparency
detail:
• Urine can be clear, cloudy, or flocculent
• Healthy urine is clear and transparent for most animals, except horse urine contains mucus and calcium carbonate crystals, and rabbit, hamster, and gerbil urine contains calcium salts, both leading to transparent but cloudy urine
• Cloudy urine may be due to RBCs, WBCs, epithelial cells, crystals, bacteria, casts, mucus, semen, lipids
• Flocculent appearance indicates pathology—easily visible particles, mucus, and other debris—often due to crystals and/or infection

title: Urine volume
detail:
• Output is controlled by amount of water animal drinks, environmental temperature, physical activity, animal’s size, and genus/species
• Pollakiuria: Frequent urination
• Polyuria: Voiding excessive amounts of urine (often in DM)
• Oliguria: Abnormally small amounts of urine (possible in case of shock, dehydration, kidney failure)
• Anuria: Inability to urinate (renal shutdown or obstruction)

title: Urine concentration
detail:
• Water deprivation/urine concentration test allows measuring endogenous antidiuretic hormone—animal is denied water over 3-5 days, which should lead to ADH release to increase renal absorption to conserve water, and result in a loss of 5% of body weight
• Specific gravity for normal levels of ADH is 1.025
• Lower concentrations may indicate insufficient ADH or tubular dysfunction
• Azotemic animals (high serum urea) shouldn’t be given this test

title: Urine odor
detail:
• May indicate bacterial infection, excess ammonia, presence of ketones (sweet, fruity smell)
• Ammonia smell indicates bacteria
• Ketones indicate DM, or pregnancy toxemia in sheep, or acetonemia in cows

title: Urine chemistry
detail:
• Part of urinalysis; analyzes urine's chemical makeup to assess kidney/urinary health and detect systemic issues like diabetes, liver disease, or infections
• Looks at parameters like pH, specific gravity, protein, glucose, ketones, and blood
• Uses non-centrifuged, room temp urine sample

title: Conditions concerning urine
detail:
• Dysuria is difficulty or painful urination
• Proteinuria is protein in the urine
• Common in glomerular disease due to leakage of large protein molecules through the glomerular filter
• Hematuria is blood in the urine
• Pyuria or leukocyturia is excessive number of WBCs in urine
• Pyuria indicates inflammation in the urinary tract

title: Mucus in urine
detail: • Horses have a large number of mucous glands located within the renal pelvis, so normal equine urine may appear thick and mucoid

title: Specific gravity
detail:
• Ratio of density of urine to density of distilled water
• Measures of how efficiently kidneys concentrate urine
• Uses non-centrifuged, room temp urine sample
• Values depend on species:
• Dogs: 1.001 to 1.060; average of 1.025
• Cats: 1.001 to 1.080; average of 1.030
• Horses: Average of 1.035
• Cattle/Swine: Average of 1.015
• Sheep: Average of 1.030
• Too high means abnormal amounts of water are eliminated, caused by dehydration, shock, or acute renal disease
• Too low may be due to large volume of water intake or renal disease

title: Measuring specific gravity
detail:
• Refractometer, urinometer, or reagent test strips are used
• Urinometer is placed inside the container holding urine to float w assistance of a weighted bulb; scale attached to the bulb is read when index stops moving
• Reagent strips are the least reliable, but quick—results are inconsistent when above 1.030

title: Isosthenuria
detail:
• When specific gravity of urine approaches that of glomerular filtrate (1.008–1.012)
• Means the urine is neither diluted nor concentrated; represents kidney disease—65% kidney function must be lost before this reading is possible
• Isosthenuria in the presence of azotemia (elevated BUN/crea) confirms kidney disease
• Animals w chronic renal failure frequently produce isosthenuric urine
• The closer the specific gravity is to isosthenuric, the greater the amount of lost kidney function

title: Hypo- and hypersthenuria
detail:
• Isosthenuria is when urine SG approaches that of glomerular filtrate (1.008–1.012)
• Hyposthenuria is anything below 1.008—indicates proper dilation of urine by tubules, which lowers specific gravity
• Hypersthenuria (baruria) is above 1.012 or 1.013—indicates that tubules are concentrating urine to hold on to water

title: Proteinuria
detail:
• Associated w urogenital system malfunctions
• Protein should be absent or minimal in urine
• Reagent strip is used to determine protein level (soaked strip is compared to color chart), but reacts more to albumin than globulin
• Results inconsistent, and false results common; see if there is blood in urine, and examine microscopic residue

title: Glucosuria
detail:
• Presence of glucose in urine (vs. glycosuria—presence of sugars in urine)
• May indicate diabetes, inability of kidneys to reabsorb glucose in renal tubules, but can also be induced by anxiety, agitation, IV fluids containing glucose, etc.
• Normal levels are 170-180 mg/dL
• Reagent strips (Clinitest or Ames) can identify glucose, but reagent tablets can identify various forms of sugars

title: Ketonuria
detail:
• Ketones are organic compounds like acetone, acetoacetic acid, and beta-hydroxybutyric acid, which are created during the metabolic processing of fats
• Ketones are produced as a result of fatty acid breakdown—since diabetic patients can’t utilize glucose, they get energy from fatty acids, leading to excess ketone production and ketonuria
• Occurs w metabolic diseases involving increased lipid or impaired carbohydrate metabolism, such as diabetic ketoacidosis in dogs and cats, starvation and ketosis in cattle (in the absence of sufficient carbohydrates, fat is used as energy source)
• Also seen in dairy cattle in the 6 weeks following parturition (lactating cows)
• Large amounts of ketones can be toxic—rapid fat metabolism can lead to ketonuria and lower carbohydrate metabolism
• Reagent strips and tablets are used (Ketostix, Acetest, Ames)

title: Hematuria
detail:
• Presence of intact RBCs in the urine
• Reddish to black, cloudy tint
• During centrifugation, as only intact RBCs settle, color of supernatant will change from red to clear
• 5 or more RBCs per HPF may indicate trauma, calculi, UTI, neoplasia
• Both reagent strips/tablets and microscopic examination
• Leukocyte test pads not recommended bc of false-positives in cats and false-negatives in dogs

title: Urine cytology – centrifugation and storage
detail:
• Cells tend to break down rapidly in urine, so should be centrifuged immediately; cells should then be removed from the supernatant
• If the specimen cannot be centrifuged immediately, it should be refrigerated and not be allowed to sit at room temperature (bacteria can proliferate and cells will degrade)
• Urine should never be frozen for cytological evaluation

title: Urine sediment
detail:
• Examined microscopically
• Specimen is blended to distribute contents and then centrifuged (conical tip) at 1,500-2,000 rpm for 3-5 min
• 0.3 mL of residual supernatant is then removed, and sediment is dispersed w/in the residual liquid in suspension; 2-3 drops of liquid enough for exam
• First observed under reduced illumination 10x (i.e. low power field objective) to see crystals, cats, squamous cells, all recorded as number per low power field (LPF)
• Then observed under 40x (i.e. high power field objective) to examine smaller crystals, cells, sperm, bacteria, all recorded as number per high power field (LPF)

title: RBCs and WBCs in urine sediment
detail:
• RBCs appear pale yellow, smaller than WBCs
• More than 5 RBCs/HPF is abnormal
• WBCs appear 1.5 larger than RBCs
• Neutrophils most common (spherical, granulated)
• More than 5 WBCs/HPF indicate inflammation and infection
• Presence of more than 5-8/HPF leukocytes indicate pyuria (pus) and/or leukocyturia, may be due to active inflammatory disease in the urogenital tract
• Any bacteria observed should be noted

title: Urine concentration for analysis
detail: • Morning samples are most concentrated and least affected by dietary factors, thereby increasing the chances of finding formed elements

title: Epithelial cells in the urine sediment
detail:
• Squamous cells can be from epithelial membranes in the vagina, vulva, urethra—largest, flat, uneven shaped, sharp edges, small and round nucleus—not a clinical finding
• Transitional epithelial cells derive from bladder, ureters, renal pelvis—varied diameter, eccentric nucleus, pear shaped, w granular cytoplasm—more than 1/HPF indicate inflammation and cystitis
• Renal epithelial cells are from renal tubules; smallest cells in the sample—looks like but larger than WBCs, circular, w sizable nucleus—large quantities may indicate renal tubule disease

title: Normal and abnormal components in a urine sediment
detail:
• Fat droplets, artifacts, epithelial cells, and contaminants may be seen
• If more than a few erythrocytes, leukocytes, hyperplastic, and/or neoplastic cells are identified, it is considered abnormal and further diagnostic tests should be performed
• Presence of WBCs indicates inflammation somewhere in the urogenital tract
• Presence of RBCs indicates bleeding in the urogenital tract

title: Casts
detail:
• Made up of protein; formed in distal renal tubules or distal nephron, embedding in itself any structure present at the time of its formation
• May indicate renal degeneration, irritation, chronic nephritis
• Casts dissolve in alkaline urine (including urine that has been standing)
• A few hyaline or granular casts is normal
• All casts are cylindric with parallel sides
• Casts may be disrupted w high-speed centrifugation and rough sample handling

title: Types of casts
detail:
• RBC casts—indicate bleeding w/in nephron
• WBC casts—indicate inflammation of tubules
• Hyaline casts—indicate renal irritation (not severe)
• Granular casts—indicate renal disease if large numbers
• Epithelial casts—indicate acute nephritis and renal tubule degeneration
• Fatty casts—indicate DM in dogs, renal disease in cats
• Waxy casts—indicate acute tubular degeneration

title: Crystals
detail:
• Struvite crystals
• Bilirubin crystals
• Calcium carbonate crystals
• Amorphous crystals
• Calcium oxalate crystals

title: Crystalluria
detail:
• Crystals in urine sediment is often of no clinical significance
• Crystal formation is temperature dependent—if urine is allowed to cool, dissolved substances come out of solution
• There may be a correlation bw crystalluria and presence of uroliths and other factors must be considered (pH, specific gravity, etc.)

title: Struvite crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image22.png]]
detail:
• Aka triple phosphate or magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals due to 3- or 6-sided prism shape
• Look like coffin lids; no color
• Common in healthy dog and cat urine—not related to struvite urolith (bladder stone) formation unless there is also a bacterial infection
• Typically observed in alkaline urine, but may be found in modestly acidic samples too

title: Bilirubin crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image19.png]]
detail:
• Small, yellow, granular/needle-like appearance
• Normal in dogs
• Indicative of hepatic dysfunction in cats, equids, bovids, camelids

title: Calcium carbonate crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image13.png]]
detail:
• Circular or oval w radial markings
• No color or yellowish
• Look like bicycle wheels
• Common in horses, rabbits, goats, cattle
• N/A in dogs and cats

title: Amorphous crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image06.png]]
detail:
• Amorphous phosphates are found in alkaline samples
• Amorphous urates are found in acidic samples
• Both look like precipitation w grainy texture
• Brownish/yellowish
• Appear in clusters w/out a specific shape

title: Calcium oxalate dihydrate and monohydrate crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image01.png]]   [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image23.png]]
detail:
• May result in formation of calcium oxalate uroliths, especially if found in large numbers
• Calcium oxalate urolithiasis has become common in cats
• Calcium oxalate dihydrate crystals occur in normal urine of any pH; look like envelopes or pyramids
• Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals are normal in horses, but not in healthy dogs and cats; look like dumbbells
• A different form that looks like colorless picket fence posts form in case of ethylene glycol toxicity (in neutral to acidic urine)

title: Ammonium biurate crystals [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image16.png]]
detail:
• Seen in slightly acidic, neutral, or alkaline urine
• Brown and round w long, irregular spicules (thorn apple)
• Most common in animals w severe liver disease

title: Urolithiasis
detail:
• Occurrence of uroliths are calculi/stones anywhere in the urinary tract
• Prevention and prognosis depend on proper identification of the composition of uroliths
• Common in male ruminants; usually composed of calcium, magnesium, ammonium carbonate (or ammonium phosphate)
• Uroliths in dogs and cats are usually struvites; cystine and oxalate possible as well
• Struvites are infection-induced; antibiotic administration may be needed for 2 to 3 months
• Calcium oxalate urolithiasis has become common in cats
• Dalmatians have most problems w uric acid stones (because they lack the enzyme uricase to break down the uric acid)

title: Fecal samples
detail:
• Exam for parasite eggs should be done asap, but may be kept refrigerated up to a week
• For giardia testing, samples should be obtained directly from the rectum for the SNAP test; fecal floatation should be run right away since trophozoites won’t survive storage
• May be sent out as is, or mixed w 10% formalin at 1:3

title: Direct smear of fecal samples
detail:
• Best fresh, near body temp, to make sure trophozoites are recognizable (much harder when they lose motility)
• Lugol’s iodine or methylene blue may be used, but not necessary
• Single drop of saline is placed on slide next to same amount of fecal sample and blended (stain applied at this point if to be used) and thinly spread
• Parasite eggs are viewed under 10x, protozoal organisms are viewed under 40x

title: Fecal floatation
detail:
• Used to find parasitic eggs
• Floatation media: Sodium nitrate (most common; for eggs, larvae, oocysts), zinc sulfate (for protozoal infections), saturated salt, saturated sodium chloride (least desired)
• Standard vial gravitation technique: 2-4 g of feces is placed in a paper cup filled w 60 mL of floatation medium and blended, poured into glass vial and filled to the top until surface is curving upward (positive meniscus), finally a coverslip is placed on top for 10 min—eggs/oocysts should float bc they have lower specific gravity than floatation medium
• Exam under 10x

title: Baermann technique
detail:
• Used to examine fecal matter for parasites, parasitic ova, and larva
• Small mount of feces is placed in paper cup, Kimwipe or cellulose tissue is placed on top of the cup and held in place w elastic, a small hole is made under the cup before it is submerged (tissue/wipe side down) in a sedimentation jar filled halfway w water
• After 12-18 hours, 3-4 samples are collected from the bottom of the sedimentation jar using a Pasteur pipette w bulb to be examined under a dissecting microscope for larval movement

title: Prepatent period
detail:
• Time between a parasitic infection occurring and when parasite's reproductive forms (like eggs or oocysts) first become detectable in the host's body
• Time of infestation to maturation
• vs. incubation period—time bw infection and symptoms

title: Strongylus vulgaris [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image09.png]]
detail:
• Equine intestinal worm
• Resides in large intestine
• Up to 25 mm long
• Prepatent period of 6-12 months
• Noninfective eggs are discharged in feces, and move from L(arvae) 1 stage to 2 remaining noninfective; larvae become infective at L3—larva sheds protective sheath upon ingestion, which allows it to migrate to and pierce the walls of the intestines at or below cecum and travel down to submucosa
• Signs include colic, fever, diarrhea, weight loss, death
• Sucks blood and causes verminous arteritis, thromboembolic colic, anemia, and debility
• Small strongyles can cause severe enteritis and diarrhea (redworm infestation)
• Diagnosed w fecal floatation

title: Coccidiosis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image07.png]]
detail:
• Intestinal parasites Isospora spp—spore-forming protozoan parasite that reproduces in small intestines of dogs and cats
• Kittens are puppies susceptible until 6 mo; high-stress, immune-compromised adults also susceptible
• Prepatent period of 4-12 days
• Infection by consumption of parasite eggs—active eggs or oocysts found in feces from infected animals
• Signs include frequent and excessive bowel movements of watery diarrhea, which may lead to dehydration or death
• Diagnosed w fecal floatation

title: Toxocara cati [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image02.png]]  [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image20.png]]
detail:
• Feline roundworm
• Infection follows eating infected host (rodent, beetle, earthworm), eggs (via vomit or feces), or drinking infected maternal milk; eggs hatch in intestines, larvae enter circulation and enter pulmonary system to get coughed up and swallowed; they then mature, reproduce more eggs to be discharged in feces (already infective)
• May be visible in vomit
• Prepatent period of 8 weeks
• Diagnosed by fecal floatation, but false-neg possible if eggs aren’t present in feces
• Signs include hypereosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, pneumonitis, fever, hyperglobulinemia; can infect eye too
• Zoonotic

title: Toxocara canis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image10.png]]
detail:
• Roundworm
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of infective egg
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Clinical signs include emaciation, intestinal blockage, vomiting, diarrhea, death; cats usually show no symptoms
• Treated w anthelmintics; deworming of puppies (at and every 2 weeks)
• Remove feces from environment to control spread
• Zoonotic potential—visceral larva migrans (VLM) and ocular larva migrans (OLM) in kids ingesting infested feces

title: Trichuris vulpis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image04.png]]
detail:
• Canine whipworm—type of nematode/roundworm
• Resides in cecum and large intestines of dogs
• Prepatent period is 3 mo
• Infection by ingestion of eggs (can persist in env for 3 years); larvae develop in small intestine, adults live in cecum, attaches to and freed on blood from intestinal wall
• Diagnosed by fecal floation
• Signs include bloody diarrhea, dehydration, weight loss

title: Giardia duodenalis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image24.png]]
detail:
• Protozoa of dogs, cats, cattle, horses, sheep, goats, pigs
• Transmitted via the fecal-oral route by ingestion of dormant cysts in contaminated food or water
• Resides in the intestines; two life cycle states—active feeding stage as trophozoite (motile w flagellum) and nonmotile cystic stage
• Prepatent period of 7-10 days
• Diagnosed by fecal floatation or direct smear
• Both cysts and trophozoites on direct fecal smear are diagnostic of Giardia
• Trophozoite has piriform (pear/teardrop) shape
• Signs include severe diarrhea

title: Ancylostoma caninum [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image17.png]]
detail:
• Canine hookworm
• Resides in the small intestine, feeding on blood from the intestinal wall
• Infection by ingestion of eggs/larvae in contaminated food, water, soil, maternal milk, infected host, or by larval penetration thru the skin
• Vertical transmission to fetus possible
• Prepatent period of 2-3 weeks
• Diagnes by fecal floatation
• Signs include anemia, weakness, melena
• Tx—fenbendazole, moxidectin, milbemycin, pyrantel

title: Dipylidium caninum [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image14.png]]
detail:
• Common tapeworm of cats and dogs (double-pore tapeworm)
• Resides in small intestines
• Older segments (gravid proglottids) found on tip of body are discarded at maturation intervals to independently reproduce (all remain active as long as host warmth is retained); once passed in feces, they open to release eggs which are eaten by adult intermediate hosts
• Infection occurs by ingesting intermediate hosts like fleas, lice, rodents, and ruminants containing larval cestodes
• Prepatent period of 3 weeks
• Often asymptomatic
• Tx—anthelmintic like broad spectrum praziquantel PO/SC

title: Intermediate forms of tapeworm
detail:
• An intermediate form of a tapeworm is its larval stage that develops in an intermediate host before becoming an adult in the intestines of the definitive host
• Hydatid cyst is the largest intermediate form
• Cysticercus, coenurus, and cysticercoid are smaller (in order from larger to smallest)

title: Strongyloides spp
detail:
• Intestinal threadworms (S. stercoralis, tumafaciens, papillosus)
• Nematodes (roundworm)
• Larvae go thru a free-living stage in the environment before becoming infective L3 that can penetrate the skin and cause migratory damage in the host

title: Skin scrapes
detail:
• 10 blade
• Sample added to a drop of mineral oil, cover slip on top
• Exam under 10x for parasites like Sarcoptes and Demodex

title: Trichography
detail:
• Hair samples (including bulbs) are plucked w hemostats
• 10-20 hairs placed on top of mineral oil for examination

title: Skin digestion
detail:
• Used for scraping samples w significant amounts of scales, epidermal shards, and debris
• Sample is placed in 15 mL conical centrifuge tube, 10 mL 4% NaOH (sodium hydroxide) solution is applied, and tube is placed in water bath and boiled for 5-10 min before being centrifuged at 1,000 rpm for 5 min
• Supernatant is poured off and sediment is placed on slide to be examined under 10x

title: Demodex canis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image08.png]]
detail:
• Causes mange (demodicosis) in dogs
• Demodex canis is a burrowing mite normally found in hair follicles and sebaceous glands, but numbers may increase when immune system is compromised
• Localized mange affects dogs younger than 1; consists of 5 small lesions of alopecia, scaling, redness around face and forelimbs
• May developed into juvenile onset generalized form due to hereditary immune abnormality
• Adult onset generalized demodectic mange results from underlying disease affecting immune system
• Diagnosed by skin scraping

title: ELISA testing for blood parasites
detail:
• Detect antigens resulting from parasitic blood infestations
• Especially useful in detecting Dirofilaria immitis
• Cannot detect microfilariae
• False negative can result from immature infections, infections w low numbers of female worms, and all-male infections
• Kit contains a wand/membrane that has parasite-specific monoclonal antibodies bound to the surface, and additional antibody is labeled w an enzyme and this plus a color-producing agent are applied to sample—if antibodies specific to the parasite are present, antibody-enzyme complex will form and produce a color (indicator), otherwise it will wash away w no color change

title: ELISA
detail:
• Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kits
• Washing is a critical step in the methodology
• Advantages are that they are rapid, easy to perform, sensitive, and specific
• Disadvantage is that results are often positive or negative and does not detect changes in titer

title: Cheyletiella [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image03.png]]
detail:
• Cheyletiellosis/mites can infect dogs, cats, rabbits
• Called walking dandruff bc mites can carry skin scales
• Entire life-cycle is on the host, but adult mite can live off the body 2-14 days
• Infection most common thru direct (physical) contact, but can also infect from environment
• Can cause pruritus, skin inflammation, crusts, swellings
• Diagnosed by skin scrape, cellophane method, combing, microscopic exam

title: Mites
detail:
• Arachnids
• Some are intermediate hosts for cestodes (tapeworms)
• Most are obligate parasites—produce mange
• Mostly transmitted thru direct contact
• Burrowing mites require deep skin scraping

title: Sarcoptiform mites
detail:
• Sarcoptidae family burrow/tunnel w/in epidermis (aka burrowing mites); Psoroptidae reside on skin surface or ear canal (non-burrowing); Demodecidae lives deep in hair follicles and sebaceous glands (follicular burrowing)
• Sarcoptidae include Sarcoptes scabiei, Notoedres cati (cats and rabbits), Knemidokoptes (birds); cause severe pruritus
• Psoroptidae include Psoroptes, Chorioptes, Otodectes; cause pruritus
• Demodecidae include Demodex; nonpruritic
• Sarcoptic mange is characterized by loss of hair and intense pruritus
• Host-specific; transient cross-species infestation may occur, but mites don’t reproduce on non-hosts

title: Otodectes species
detail:
• Parasite that lives in ears
• Otodectes cynotis, the ear mite, is an obligate parasite of the host but is not host specific
• The life cycle is typically completed on a single host in about 3 weeks

title: Ticks
detail:
• Blood sucking arachnids
• Tick’s head (capitulum) is used for cutting and attachment; sucking organ is the hypostome
• Two types:
• Hard ticks (Ixodidae) are vectors of protozoal, bacterial, viral, rickettsial diseases
• Soft ticks (Argasidae) lack scutum (chitinous covering); they are ectoparasites of birds
• Larval stage has six legs
• Ticks mate on animals, drop eggs to ground, which then hatch into larvae and climb on vegetation or small mammal host, once fed these molt into nymphs, crawl up vegetation and attach on a host, feed again, and drop back on ground to molt into adults, and use vegetation to get back on a host

title: Tick paralysis
detail:
• Can be caused by saliva of females of some species
• Include Dermacentor adersoni (Rocky Mountain spotted fever tick), Dermacentor accidentalis (Pacific coast tick), Ixodes holocylus (Australian paralysis tick), and Dermacentor variabilis (wood tick)

title: Notable ticks
detail:
• Dermacentor variabilis is the American dog tick
• Rhipicephalus sanguineus is the brown dog tick
• Ixodes dammini is the deer tick
• Dermacentor albipictus is the winter tick

title: Common tick-borne diseases
detail:
• Lyme disease (dogs, humans, rare in cats)
• Agent: Borrelia burgdorferi
• Vector: Ixodes (deer tick)
• Causes lameness, fever, lethargy, lymphadenopathy
• Ehrlichiosis (dogs)
• Agent: Ehrlichia canis (most common)
• Vector: Brown dog tick (Rhipicephalus)
• Causes fever, thrombocytopenia, bleeding
• Anaplasmosis (dogs, humans)
• Agent: Anaplasma phagocytophilum / A. platys
• Vector: Ixodes, Rhipicephalus
• Causes lameness, fever, thrombocytopenia
• Babesiosis (dogs)
• Agent: Babesia spp.
• Vector: Varies
• Causes hemolytic anemia, weakness, jaundice
• Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (dogs, humans—zoonotic)
• Agent: Rickettsia rickettsii
• Vector: Dermacentor ticks
• Causes fever, petechiae, edema, neurologic signs
6. Hepatozoonosis
Agent: Hepatozoon canis
Transmission: Ingestion of infected tick (not bite)
Species: Dogs
Key signs: Fever, muscle pain, weakness

title: Acariasis
detail: • Infestation by mites or ticks

title: Pediculosis
detail: • Infestation by lice

title: Ctenocephalides spp. (felis & canis) [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image25.png]]
detail:
• Fleas—reddish brown-black in color
• Lay eggs on host’s skin, which then fall in the environment, and, once hatched in 1-6 days, larvae live on organic debris and adult flea feces, mature and spin a cocoon to reside in, and come out as adults in 1-2 weeks once they sense a nearby host (pupa can remained in cocoon for 350 days waiting for a host)
• Can cause allergy dermatitis—inflammation that appears red, is itchy or swollen

title: Phthiraptera [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image18.png]]
detail:
• Lice
• Lay eggs (aka nits) glued to hair shaft to remain w host
• Transferred w physical contact
• Can remain on host for entire life cycle
• Suborder Anoplura is sucking lice, and suborder Mallophaga is chewing lice
• Each have different species that infect each species of animal (some animals are susceptible to multiple)
• May cause itchiness, scruffy, dry, brittle hair

title: Dermatophytes [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image11.png]]
detail:
• Ringworm
• Microsporum canis and gypseum, and Tricophyton mentagrophytes most common
• Diagnosed w DTM (dermatophyte test medium) culture—dermatophytes metabolize the protein in the medium and release alkaline metabolites that turn the medium red
• Microscopic exam is done after 2 weeks of keeping DTM in a dark place and checking daily under 40x w new methylene blue
• Skin or hair samples may also be examined w/out culture

title: Microsporum canis
detail:
• Genera of dermatophytes (ringworm)
• Causes most infections in cats and dogs
• If the fungus is at the right stage of development, (50% of cases), it will appear apple-green under Wood’s lamp

title: Buffy coat method for blood parasites
detail:
• Buffy coat (middle layer after centrifugation) contains WBCs, platelets, and some parasites
• Buffy coat exams help detect parasites ass w WBCs or free plasma (not those ass w RBCs)
• A drop of saline and a drop of methylene blue is added on top of the buffy coat on the slide, a coverslip is applied, and sample is observed for microfilariae

title: Modified Knott’s technique
detail:
• Used to identify and quantify parasites in the blood
• Blood-borne parasites are classified as rickettsial (bacterial), protozoal, helminth (parasitic worms), viral
• 1 mL EDTA blood and 9 mL of water or 2% formalin is mixed to cause hemolysis and centrifuged for 1,000 rpm for 5 min (or set aside for 1 hour); supernatant is decanted off and 2 drops of methylene blue is added on the undisturbed sediment; solution is mixed gently by aspirating w a pipette
• Sample is observed under 10x to microfilariae or larva

title: Dirofilaria immitis [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image26.png]]
detail:
• Canine heartworm—can infect dogs, cats, and other animals thru a mosquito or transplacental infection
• Mosquito is both intermediate host and vector
• Lifespan is much shorter (3 vs 7 years) in cats, and worm burden is much less too, so doesn’t cause severe disease
• Prepatent period if 6-8 mo (so newborn will be 6 mo before it becomes detectable)
• Signs include lethargy, exercise intolerance, cough, severe weight loss when chronic, can lead to CHF
• Heavy infection or high activity levels lead to earlier signs
• Adult worms release larvae into blood (L1), mosquito bites infected dog and ingests L1 larvae, which matures into L3 w/in mosquito, another bite transfers larvae to a dog to mature first into L4 and infest muscles and vessels, and then into an adult to infest pulmonary artery and heart
• Modified Knott’s, or wet or Giemsa-stained smears used to test for microfilariae, but buffy coat is most accurate; SNAP test used for adult heartworm

title: Babesia spp.
detail:
• Blood-borne parasitic protozoan that cause babesiosis in dogs, cattle, horses, sheep, goats, pigs
• Transmitted by ticks
• Parasites are found inside RBCs

title: Botflies Gasterophilus Oestrus Hypoderma Cuterebra
detail:
• Adults don’t feed; leave eggs at entrance of animal burrows, which then hatch and penetrate the skin of host
• Larvae develop in GI tract of horses (Gasterophilus/horse botfly), nasal passages of sheep (Oestrus), dorsal subcutis of cow (Hypoderma)
• Cuterebra are found in rabbits, rodents, cats, dogs, and humans; form large pockets in SC tissue or live in air holes (aka warbles); female flies lay eggs along burrows and first-stage larvae hatch instantaneously and crawl into host’s fur, enter host thru natural openings and migrate to SC location
• Can infect humans

title: Prokaryotic vs. eukaryotic cells
detail:
• Prokaryotes are single-celled organisms w no nucleus or specialized organelles
• Bacteria
• Eukaryotes have a nucleus and specialized organelles; usually have an outer cell membrane, inner cytoplasm and a nucleus

title: Organelles
detail:
• Cytoplasm contains cytosol and organelles
• Organelles include:
• Ribosomes
• Mitochondria
• Endoplasmic reticulum
• Golgi bodies

title: Ribosomes
detail:
• Manufacture proteins—read RNA produced by DNA and translate it into proteins
• Free-floating in the cytoplasm in small clusters or attached to endoplasmic reticula

title: Mitochondria
detail:
• Transform organic substances from foods into ATP
• Make up 25% of the cytoplasm

title: Endoplasmic reticulum
detail: • Network of tubes that alters and transports proteins, produces macromolecules (i.e. glycogen and natural steroids), and sequesters calcium

title: Golgi bodies
detail: • Process cellular products, releasing them back into the cell or excreting as needed

title: Viral replication
detail:
• A virion consists of genetic material (DNA/RNA) and a capsid, the protective protein shell surrounding the genetic material
• Both RNA and DNA viruses require host for replication
• Viral entry occurs at mucosal membranes (respiratory, GI, or urogenital tract) w virus fastening onto mucosal cells; it then uses the nucleic acid replication infrastructure of the cell to replicate its own genetic material and proteins
• Release from cells occurs by lysis (upon death of host cell) or budding (cytopathic as opposed to cytolytic)
• Viruses are obligate parasites; not free-living
• They can only grow inside cells, so they are intracellular parasites

title: Growth media
detail:
