• Trypticase soy agar (TSA): Used to study bacterial hemolytic reactions; some are enriched w blood to propagate fastidious organisms
• Blood agar: Similar medium w 5% sheep blood
• Trypticase soy broth (TSE): Cultures most bacteria
• MacConkey II Agar (MAC): For gram-neg bacteria; crystal violet and bile salts used to hinder gram-pos growth; also incorporates a neutral red indicator that changes to pink or purple in case of lactose fermentation to differentiate lactose-fermenting and non-lactose-fermenting bacteria; inhibits growth of Proteus species
• Columbia Colistin-Nalidixic Agar (C-CAN): Combines the antibiotic colistin (against intestinal infections) w nalidixic acid; for gram-pos bacteria; contains 5% sheep blood
• Salmonella-Shigella Agar (SS): Specific to salmonella and shigella; employs lactose fermentation-generated color changes and ferric citrate so that hydrogen sulfide producing bacteria causes black coloration
• Campylobacter Agar w 5 Antimicrobics and 10% Sheep Blood (Campy BAP): Very sensitive; mostly used for developing Campylobacter spp

title: Blood agar
detail:
• Type of culture media—enrichment medium and differential medium
• Supports growth of most bacterial pathogens
• Several types available, trypticase soy agar w sheep blood most common
• Four types of hemolysis can be detected:
• Alpha: Partial hemolysis that creates a narrow band of greenish or slimy discoloration around the colony
• Beta: Complete hemolysis that creates a clear zone around the colony
• Delta: Zone of hemolysis surrounded by narrow zone of hemolysis around the colony (aka double-zone hemolysis)
• Gamma: No change in the medium, no hemolysis around the colony

title: Colonies in blood agar
detail:
• Proteus sp. is often seen swarming without distinct colonies
• Pseudomonas sp. appears as an irregular spreading w grayish colonies; has variable hemolysis and may show a metallic sheen on a blood agar plate
• Staphylococcus sp. appears smooth and glistening, w pigmented colonies that are white to yellow
• Escherichia coli will appear large and gray, w smooth mucoid colonies; hemolysis will be variable

title: Mannitol salt agar
detail:
• Highly selective medium for staphylococci
• Can be used to isolate Staphylococcus aureus
• Not routinely used
• Has a high salt content and pH indicator phenol red

title: Gram staining
detail:
• Requires a primary stain, a mordant, a decolorizer, and a counterstain, so not considered a simple stain
• Specimen retrieved from colony on plate
• Following heat-fixing, slide is dipped into iodine for 1 min, rinsed, dipped into decolorizer for 10 sec, rinsed, and dipped into safranin counterstain for 30-50 sec, rinsed, and air-dried
• Slide is viewed under oil immersion (100x)
• Bacteria that look purple to dark blue are gram-positive
• Bacteria that look pink are gram-negative
• Gram-positive organisms retain crystal violet stain and appear purple, whereas gram-negative organisms do not retain crystal violet but counterstain with safranin, and appear pink
• Iodine in Gram stain fixes the crystal violet to the bacterial cell wall of the gram-positive bacteria, and decolorizer removes the crystal violet from gram-negative bacteria

title: Acid-fast staining (Ziehl-Neelsen stain)
detail:
• Used to detect acid-fast organisms Mycobacterium (tuberculosis) and Nocardia
• Consist of primary stain (DMSO or carbol fuchsin), acid-alcohol decolorizer, and counterstain like methylene blue
• Slide is air dried and heat fixed
• Acid-fast organisms stain pink to red
• Non-acid-fast organisms stain blue

title: Diff-Quik
detail:
• A Romanowsky stain, so sample must be air-dried first
• Bone marrow smears are much thicker than blood smears, so a longer period of staining time is necessary to identify adequately the cells (i.e. dip smear twice as long)

title: Supravital stains
detail:
• Contain no fixatives
• Include new methylene blue, brilliant cresyl blue
• Reticulocytes (immature RBCs) need to be stained with these stains for identification
• When reticulocytes are stained with a supravital stain, organelles clump into granules that are referred to as reticulum (chains of blue granules)

title: Lactophenol cotton blue
detail: • Used for the identification of fungal elements

title: Innate immune system
detail:
• Nonspecific—involves physical and chemical barriers
• Barriers include the skin; physical and biochemical components of nasopharynx, gut, lung, genitourinary tract; commensal bacteria
• Natural killer (NK) cells, interferons, and complement system are components of innate immune system

title: NK cells
detail:
• Natural killer cells
• Subset of lymphocytes
• Recognize and destroy host cells infected w microbes
• Also activate phagocytes by releasing interferon-y
• Interferons are cytokines that elicit other cellular reactions, and influence the actions of NK cells

title: Complement system
detail:
• Integral to both innate and adaptive immune systems
• A series of chemical reactions known as the complement cascade occurs when activated

title: Adaptive immune system
detail:
• The system that goes against foreign bodies that invade the innate immune system
• Mostly run by lymphocytes
• Divided into two components: humoral immune system and cell-mediated immune system

title: Humoral immune system
detail:
• Part of the adaptive immune system that uses B cells and antibodies to fight pathogens in the body's fluids (humors)
• Lymphocytes that mature in the bone marrow (B cells) are concerned w production of immunoglobin (Ig) molecules, aka antibodies
• Helper T cells produce cytokines that activate B cells

title: [[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image21.png]]
detail:
• IgM: First to antibody produced—high titer, low avidity (binding strength); abundant in early stages, less later; large, so unable to enter tissue; 5% of all immunoglobulin
• IgG: Small and can enter tissue, can cross placenta; usually produced during secondary immune response; low-titer, high avidity; remains in circulation longest; most abundant at 75%
• IgE: Similar to IgG, but found in very small amounts
• IgA: 20%
• IgD: Very low abundance if present

title: Active vs. passive immunity
detail:
• Active immunity: Occurs when immune system develops antibodies to antigens such as viruses, yeast, or bacteria, to which the animal can be exposed via natural exposure or by injection with a noninfectious form of the antigen in a vaccine
• Passive immunity: Occurs when animal receives antibodies from colostrum or synthesized antibodies (e.g. antitoxin administration, gamma globulin administration)
• Globulin is obtained from a donor that is vaccinated w a pathogen; immunity is short-lived

title: Hypersensitivity reactions
detail:
• Type 1 is an immediate hypersensitivity that occurs when chemical mediators are released from mast cells (e.g. allergies, anaphylactic shock, vaccine reactions); occurs when IgE antibodies are formed in response to previously encountered antigen
• Type II is antibody-mediated diseases in which antibodies are directed to own cells (e.g. IMHA); mediated by IgG binding
• Type III is immune-complex mediated diseases; occurs when antibodies and antigens form complexes that are deposited into blood vessels (e.g. systemic lupus)
• Type IV is T-cell-mediated diseases caused by the reaction of T lymphocytes against self-antigens (e.g. contact sensitivity reactions like poison ivy)

title: Role of IgE during type I hypersensitivity reactions
detail:
• Type I reactions are mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE)
• Principal cellular component is the mast cell or basophil
• Reaction is amplified or modified by eosinophils, neutrophils, and platelets
• Type I hypersensitivity reaction triggers release of histamine—mast cells and basophils normally produce a small quantity, but when IgE sensitizes them, they react abnormally, producing large quantities of histamines and other chemicals, which cause allergic attacks

title: -penia vs. -philia/-cytosis
detail:
• -penia: Decrease in the number of blood cell type
• -philia/-cytosis: Increased in the number of blood cell type

title: Transmission of FIV
detail:
• FIV is found in saliva, so bite wounds serve as means of transmission
• Mostly occur thru fighting

title: Phagocytes
detail:
• Leukocytes that ingest foreign organisms and particles.
• Specialized immune cells that engulf harmful bacteria, viruses, fungi, and cellular debris
• Include neutrophils, macrophages, monocytes

title: Combined immunodeficiency
detail:
• Absence or deficiency of immunoglobulins; failure to produce functional T or B cells
• Occurs in early life, after serum levels of maternally derived antibodies decline
• Occurs in 2-3% of Arabian foals and they often die from opportunistic infection

title: Abnormal Urinalysis Results
detail:
• A trace amount of protein may be significant in a patient with chronic renal failure—in kidney disease, excessive amounts of protein enter the glomerular filtrate and are not reabsorbed, resulting in protein in the urine
• Diabetes cases may have glucosuria and ketonuria
• Hemolytic anemia cases have hematuria and bilirubinuria
• If a patient is experiencing an acid-base imbalance, there will be a change in the pH of the urine

title: Urine pH
detail:
• Factors that may decrease pH (and lead to acidic urine) include fever, starvation, high-protein diet, acidosis, excessive muscular activity, certain drug, diabetes, and prolonged diarrhea
• Factors that may increase pH (and lead to alkaline urine) include alkalosis, high-fiber diets, UTI due to urease bacteria, certain drugs, and urine retention, such as that which occurs with urethral obstruction or bladder paralysis

title: Fructosamine
detail:
• Glucose can bind a variety of structures, including proteins; when glucose concentrations are persistently elevated (DM), increased binding of glucose to proteins occurs
• Fructosamine represents the irreversible reaction of glucose bound to albumin
• Finding of increased fructosamine indicates hyperglycemia
• Half-life of albumin in dogs and cats is 1 to 2 weeks, so fructosamine provides an indication of the average serum glucose throughout that period

title: Hemocytometer
detail:
• Precision microscope slide that aids in manual cell count
• Counting chamber used to determine number of cells per microliter of blood (µl or mm3)
• Has two sets of grids of parallel and perpendicular etched lines called Neubauer rulings; each grid is divided into 9 squares with each of the 4 corners divided into 16 smaller squares and center divided into 400 very small squares—the area of each grid is designed to hold a specific amount of sample (0.9 µl)
• Number of cells counted in each area is then converted into cells per unit volume

title: Corrected leukocyte (WBC) count
detail:
• nRBCs are included in total WBC count by hemocytometers and electronic cell counters, resulting in falsely increased WBC counts
• A correction is done using a formula:
Corrected leukocyte count = (measured leukocyte count x 100)
(100 + nRBC)

title: Symptoms of parathyroidism
detail:
• Usually none
• Diagnosed w serum chemistry

title: Functions of the liver
detail:
• Metabolism of amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids
• Synthesis of albumin, cholesterol, plasma proteins, clotting factors
• Digestion/absorption of nutrients related to bile formation
• Secretion of bilirubin and bile
• Elimination via detoxification of toxins and catabolism of some drugs
• All functions are controlled by enzymatic reactions
• Gallbladder stores bile; functions closely w liver
• Malfunctions in either leads to jaundice, hypoalbuminemia, hemostasis problems, hypoglycemia, hyperlipoproteinemia, hepatoencephalopathy

title: Tests of liver function (hepatobiliary assays)
detail:
• Due to very wide range of its functions, there are many tests of liver function
• Bile acids (preprandial and postprandial) are the function test of choice for liver function—evaluates the major anatomic component of the hepatobiliary system
• Also include ammonia assay, bilirubin, and alanine aminotransferase, AST, AP, serum albumin, and dye excretion
• Cholestatic enzymes, hepatocellular leakage enzymes, and total protein and albumin are all associated w liver function
• In horses, gamma-glutamyl transferase and sorbitol dehydrogenase are measured to evaluate liver function

title: Spleen
detail:
• Has both lymphatic and hematologic functions
• Produces some blood alongside bone marrow
• Acts as a reservoir for blood when the animal is at rest and does not need a large amount of oxygen and other substances to be delivered to the muscles
• Has storage sinuses for blood until it is needed

title: Cytokines
detail:
• Small proteins that act as chemical messengers
• Enable immune cells to communicate, coordinate responses, and regulate inflammation, growth, differentiation, and infection fighting
• Include interleukins, interferons, chemokines, and tumor necrosis factors

title: Erythropoiesis
detail:
• Erythropoietin is the primary cytokine responsible for RBC production
• Erythropoietin is mostly produced in the kidney in response to decreased oxygen in blood, and travels to bone marrow and binds to receptors on erythroid precursor cells, causing it to divide and mature
• Precursor cells mature in the following order—rubriblast, rubricyte, reticulocyte, erythrocyte
[[image:Lab Procedures Flashcards_Image15.png]]

title: Nematodes vs. cestodes vs. trematodes
detail:
• Nematodes (roundworms)
• Round, cylindrical; unsegmented body
• Include ascarids, hookworms, whipworms; Toxocara canis, Ancylostoma caninum, Trichuris vulpis, Dirofilaria immitis
• Mnemonic: NEMA = noodles
• Cestodes (tapeworms)
• Flat, ribbon-like; segmented (proglottids)
• Include Taenia, Dipylidium; D. caninum
• Trematodes (flukes)
• Flat, leaf-shaped; unsegmented body
• Include Fasciola species (inc. liver fluke), or Alaria (intestinal fluke), lung fluke like Paragonimus kellicotti

title: Nosocomial vs. iatrogenic
detail:
• Nosocomial diseases originate in a hospital; hospital-acquired diseases
• Infection acquired during surgery is nosocomial
• Iatrogenic diseases result from the activity of the veterinarian or from any adverse condition in a patient that results from treatment by a veterinarian

title: Scabies
detail:
• Aka sarcoptic mange
• Disease caused by Sarcoptes scabei, which is a burrowing mite

title: Capillary action (capillarity)
detail:
• Occurs when a liquid pushes against a solid and is caused to rise
• Example is blood entering a hematocrit tube

title: Cells produced in the bone marrow
detail:
• Erythrocytes
• Leukocytes
• Platelets
• Bone marrow is the secondary location of lymphocyte production; they are produced in lymphoid organs and peripheral lymphoid tissue like thymus, lymph nodes, spleen, tonsils

title: Staphylococcus spp.
detail:
• Both normal resident cutaneous microflora and opportunistic pathogens
• Found in pyoderma in dogs and cats
• Common pathogen in mastitis, skin wounds, and abscesses that is also found in the environment
• Can wall itself off from treatment and still produce toxins that might kill the host

title: Clotting at room temp
detail: • A red-top Vacutainer tube should sit at room temperature for 30 min before centrifugation to allow a clot to form

title: Blood collection for coagulation profile
detail:
• Blood should be collected via a single venipuncture to avoid cell damage and excessive activation of coagulation factors
• Trauma during venipuncture interferes with the results of a coagulation profile by increasing the blood’s coagulability
• Blue citrate-containing Vacutainer should be used for collection
• It is not necessary to test the sample immediately

title: Crossmatching
detail:
• Reduces possibility of transfusion reaction
• Major crossmatching: Recipient serum is added to donor RBCs, incubated, centrifuged, and examined macroscopically and microscopically for hemolysis or agglutination (either indicates mismatch)
• Minor crossmatching: Recipient RBCs are added to donor serum
• Major crossmatch determines compatibility of donor’s RBCs w recipient’s serum; minor crossmatch determines compatibility of donor’s serum with recipient’s RBCs—both should be done for animals w unknown blood types

title: Coombs test
detail:
• Detects presence of inappropriate antibodies (auto-antibodies)
• Direct Coombs test: Sample is incubated w antisera, which reacts w immunoglobulins—if RBCs are coated w immunoglobulin (self-antibody), these will react w antisera and result in visible agglutination of RBCs
• Detects antibodies already attached to RBCs
• Used to diagnose immune-mediated hemolytic disease
• Indirect Coombs test: Patient serum is mixed w test RBCs, then anti-globulin reagent is added—if antibodies are present, agglutination will occur
• Detects free antibodies in the serum—looks for circulating antibodies that could bind RBCs
• Used in blood typing and crossmatching, and detecting alloantibodies before transfusion

title: Aspartate transaminase (AST) (aspartate aminotransferase)
detail:
• One of the enzymes released from damaged hepatocytes
• Enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from aspartic acid to alpha-ketoglutaric acid, thereby forming glutamic acid and oxaloacetic acid
• Horses have higher normal AST values than other species

title: Leakage enzymes
detail:
• Hepatocyte damage leads to leakage of liver enzymes into the blood, leading to rise in blood levels of enzymes associate w liver cells
• Include:
• Transferase enzymes alanine transaminase (ALT), aspartate transaminase (AST)
• Dehydrogenase enzymes iditol dehydrogenase (ID), glutamate dehydrogenase (GLDH)

title: Pemphigus
detail: • Autoimmune skin disease that attacks the skin and mucosa

title: Yersinia pestis
detail:
• Bacterium that causes the bubonic plague
• Zoonotic
• Transmitted via fleas
• Rats are the reservoir host generally, but in western US it is prairie dogs

title: Borrelia burgdorferi
detail:
• Lyme disease
• Vector is Ixodex scapularis (deer tick)—doesn’t cause the disease itself, but serves as the vector and intermediate host for the bacteria that causes it

title: Vector vs. intermediate host vs. paratenic host
detail:
• A vector is an organism (like a mosquito or tick) that transports a pathogen
• Intermediate host is an organism where a parasite develops before moving to the final host for sexual reproduction
• Paratenic host is an organism that carries a parasite to a new host w/out allowing it to develop or reproduce

title: ACTH stimulation test
detail:
• Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulates adrenocortical growth and secretion—cortisol is released, which in turn inhibits corticotropin-releasing factor and ACTH
• ACTH stimulation test is used to distinguish iatrogenic and spontaneous hyperadrenocorticism, or to test efficacy of therapies
• Test evaluates degree of adrenal gland response to administration of exogenous ACTH—degree of response should be in proportion to gland’s size and development (hyperplastic adrenal glands have exaggerated responses, hypoplastic glands have diminished responses)
• Detects abnormalities, but not the cause

title: Blood typing
detail:
• Methods include tube method (gold standard), immunochromatography assay, card/slide agglutination assay
• Dog blood types: DEA 1 – 3 – 4 – 5 – 7
• DEA: Dog erythrocyte antigen
• Cat blood types: A – B – AB
• 99% of domestic short and long-haired cats in US are A
• Less than 1% of cats are AB
• There is no universal cat blood donor, because cats have isoantibodies against other blood types
• Large animals: Thousands, so blood typing not practical

title: Cat vs. dog reactions to transfusions
detail:
• Transfusion reactions in cats are rare but much more severe than in dogs; may occur w first transfusion (not the case in dogs)
• Cats have naturally occurring circulating alloantibodies to the blood type they do not have—Type B cats have high levels of type A antibodies, etc.
• Transfusion of type A blood into a type B cat could result in severe, potentially fatal hemolytic transfusion reaction

title: Lymphopoiesis
detail:
• Production of T cells, B cells, natural killer cells
• Arises from the common lymphoid progenitor, proceeds thru lymphoblast and prolymphocyte stages, differentiated into B or T/NK precursor
• B cells mature in bone marrow; they migrate to the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) where they greatly increase their numbers and achieve the diversification of their B-cell receptor
• T cells mature in thymus
• NK cells mature in bone marrow, thymus, and other lymphoid tissue

title: Plasma cells
detail:
• Mass-produce antibodies
• Terminally differentiated B cells; form after B cells are activated by antigen (often with T-cell help)
• Function is to produce and secrete large quantities of antibodies

title: Memory B cells
detail:
• Lymphocytes; initiate a secondary immune response—some antigen-stimulated B cells differentiate into memory cells for faster respond upon second exposure
• Produced during initial exposure and remain to produce antibodies more quickly in case there is a second exposure

title: Which stain is used for which purpose
detail:
• Sudan III or IV is used to stain fat—fat droplets float in and out of planes of focus, usually vary in size, and stain shades of iridescent orange
• New methylene blue provides nuclear and nucleolar detail; effectively stains nuclei, mast cells, many infectious agents
• Diff-Quik can be applied rapidly to smears of aspirated cells or exudate
• Giemsa stain is used to detect spirochetes and rickettsiae, and to view the capsule of Bacillus anthracis and morphology of Dermatophilus congolensis

title: Venous vs. arterial blood for testing
detail:
• Arterial blood is most commonly used to analyze blood gasses; arterial gas sample is the best source to evaluate blood CO2 levels
• Venous blood is generally used for hematology, chemistry, and organ function tests

title: Organisms found in normal dog intestines
detail:
• Streptococci, lactobacilli, and Bifidobacterium spp.
• Several species of anaerobic bacteria are found in the duodenum and jejunum
• Escherichia coli is present in the ileum

title: Streptococcus spp.
detail:
• Opportunistic pathogens that normally reside in the upper respiratory, intestinal, lower urinary, and genital tracts
• Can cause localized infection or septicemia in dogs of all ages
• Streptococcus equi causes strangles in horses

title: Fibrinogen
detail:
• Protein involved in blood coagulation
• Most abundant coagulation factor in the body
• Produced by the liver
• Increases in inflammatory processes; detection is useful especially in ruminants
• Plasma fibrinogen concentrations are measured using heat precipitation—EDTA blood is centrifuged, tube broken above buffy coat and dispensed in a hemocytometer prism to get the total protein number; second tube is heated in a water bath at 56C/132.8F for 3 min to precipitate fibrinogen, respun so it settles right above buffy coat, and total protein is measured
Fibrinogen concentration (mg/dL) = (TP1 – TP2) x 100

title: Plasmin
detail: • The enzyme that digests fibrin threads and other clotting products to cause clot lysis

title: von Willebrand factor
detail:
• Serves to stabilize the platelet plug during the mechanical phase of blood coagulation
• Required for platelet adhesion
• Deficiencies in von Willebrand factor leads to prolonged bleeding time

title: von Willebrand disease
detail:
• Most common inherited coagulation disorder of domestic animals (common in Dobermans, rabbits, pigs)
• Results from decreased production of von Willebrand factor
• Can be stimulated by hypothyroidism if a dog is already predisposed to it
• It’s a disorder of primary hemostasis (i.e. coagulation cascade is normal), buccal mucosal bleeding time is the best screening test presurgery (ACT and APPT evaluate secondary hemostasis)
• A vWF assay is performed when platelet function defects are evident

title: Azotemia
detail:
• Excess of urea, creatinine, and other nitrogenous end products of protein and amino acid metabolism in the blood
• Kidney disease results in accumulation of metabolic waste in the blood, i.e. azotemia
• Indicates reduced excretion of waste products; leads to higher levels of BUN and creatinine

title: Renal, prerenal, postrenal azotemia
detail:
• Azotemia = elevated BUN and creatinine due to decreased excretion
• Azotemia as a localization problem: Where along the urine-production pathway things are going wrong
• Prerenal: dehydration with normal kidneys → high SG
• Renal: kidney dysfunction → low or inappropriate SG despite dehydration
• Postrenal: obstruction or rupture → waste buildup due to inability to urinate

title: Prerenal azotemia
detail:
• In cases of dehydration, kidneys conserve water by decreasing amount of urine produced and increasing urine concentration
• BUN and serum creatinine must be interpreted in conjunction w hydration status and urine specific gravity to distinguish dehydration (prerenal azotemia) from impaired kidney function (renal azotemia)
• If a dehydrated patient has healthy kidneys, increases in BUN and serum creatinine will be accompanied by high urine SG, indicating that kidneys are capable of concentrating urine to conserve water
• Mechanism
• Dehydration or poor perfusion
• Kidneys themselves are structurally and functionally normal
• Reduced blood flow → reduced filtration → ↑ BUN & creatinine
• Elevated values + concentrated urine = kidneys responding appropriately

title: Renal azotemia
detail:
• Kidneys fail to concentrate urine adequately, so SG is lower than expected (despite dehydration normally increasing SG—dehydration should increase SG; if it doesn’t the kidneys are failing)
• Kidneys cannot concentrate urine
• Urine remains dilute or inadequately concentrated
• Waste products accumulate
• Low SG in a dehydrated patient = failure to compensate → renal azotemia

title: Postrenal azotemia
detail:
• Leads to an increase in BUN resulting from inability to urinate
• Back pressure reduces GFR
• Nitrogenous wastes accumulate
• BUN and creatinine increase
• Associated w urinary tract obstruction or perforation

title: Bacillus spp.
detail:
• Bacillus spp. are among the most common laboratory contaminants
• Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax in animals and human beings

title: Lipuria
detail:
• Fat in the urine
• Seen to some degree in most cats—feline renal epithelial cells have a high fat content and fat droplets are released when these cells disintegrate

title: Malassezia pachydermatis
detail: • Yeast found in cats and dogs; on skin or ears (otitis externa or dermatitis)

title: Candida
detail:
• Opportunistic fungal
• Mostly associated w avian respiratory and GI tracts

title: Cryptococcus
detail: • Fungus mostly associated w feline nasal disease

title: Microscopic movement of parasites in feces
detail:
• Tritrichomonas move actively w jerky movements (zippy motility)
• Giardia trophozoites have a falling leaf movement

title: Calcium phosphate ratio
detail:
• Calcium plays a role in bone development, transmission of nerve impulses, and muscle contraction
• Calcium concentrations are inversely related to phosphorus concentrations
• Ratio is altered by impaired kidney function—leads to increased output of parathormone (parathyroid hormone that signals bones to release calcium to increase low blood calcium levels), which results in resorption of bone in an effort to maintain blood calcium levels
• Blood chemistry analysis measures levels of calcium and phosphorus

title: Pancreatitis testing
detail:
• Amylase, lipase, and trypsin are produced and secreted by the pancreas
• Serum chemistry tests for acute pancreatitis include amylase and lipase
• Trypsin can be qualitatively measured in the feces as an assessment of chronic pancreatitis

title: Titer testing
detail:
• Titer is a measure of antibody units per unit volume of serum
• Titer testing is performed immediately after infection (acute phase) and 2 to 6 weeks after collection of the first serum sample (convalescent phase)
• IgG and IgM titers are reported individually
• A titer >1:256 for IgM is consistent with active infection in patients w clinical signs
• For IgG titer, best to submit 2 samples collected 2 to 3 weeks apart; 4x or more increase in titer during that time is indicates active infection

title: Laser-flow technology
detail: • Used to determine blood cell concentrations, WBC differential, and other hematology parameters

title: Hematopoiesis
detail: • Production of blood cells and platelets

title: Classification of anemia by bone marrow response
detail:
• Regenerative or nonregenerative anemia
• Other than in horses, bone marrow responds to anemia by increasing erythrocyte production and releasing immature erythrocytes—bone marrow being able to respond means anemia is due to blood loos or destruction (hemolysis)
• Immature RBCs are polychromatophilic RBCs or reticulocytes
• Macrocytosis, increased polychromasia, and Howell-Jolly bodies will likely be present in blood cell film
• Bone marrow samples will show erythroid hyperplasia (increased red cell production in the marrow)
• In horses, bone marrow evaluation is needed to classify anemia—reticulocyte counts of more than 5% indicate regenerative response
• Nonregenerative anemia means bone marrow is unable to respond to anemia—no reticulocytes, suggesting bone marrow dysfunction

title: Classification of anemia by etiology
detail:
• Hemolytic, hemorrhagic, or resulting from decreased/defective RBC production
• Hemolytic anemias result from RBC destruction in the blood; usually regenerative
• May be caused by immune disorders, RBC parasites, bacterial or viral agents (FIV), toxic agents (zinc, onions, acetaminophen)
• Liver disease and/or hemolytic anemia is suspected when jaundice is present
• Hemorrhagic anemia is due to blood loss (acute or chronic)
• Iron deficiency can also lead to anemia

title: Moraxella bovis
detail: • Gram-negative diplococcus that causes pinkeye in cattle

title: Effects of various chemicals on different tests
detail:
• Increased ALT will result from acetaminophen, aflatoxin, benzimidazole anthelmintics, halogenated hydrocarbons (e.g., halothane, chloroform), hydrocarbon solvents, iron, melaleuca oil, mushrooms (Amanita spp.), phosphides, sago palm, xylitol, and zinc
• Increased ammonia may be caused by ingestion of ammonium based fertilizers
• Blood pH may change due to ingestion of alcohols, bread dough, and ethylene glycol
• Calcium may increase due to ingestion of Calcipotriene, cholecalciferol rodenticide, diuretics, grapes/raisins, hops, or xylitol

title: Bacterial endospores
detail:
• Survival capsules that allow the organisms to survive harsh environments
• Resistant to heat, desiccation, chemicals, and radiation

title: Bacterial cell shapes
detail:
• Coccus: Spherical (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus)
• Bacillus: Shaped like rod/cylinder (e.g. Bacillus anthracis)
• Spiral/spirochetes: Can be single or loose spirals (e.g. Borrelia anserine)
• Coccobacillus: Small rod-shaped bacteria that stains in a polar fashion, looking like paired cocci (e.g. Escherichia coli)
• Pleomorphic: Shapes that range from cocci to rods

title: Bile acids
detail:
• Aid in the digestion of fats by converting fats and fatty acids into maltose
• Tested to assess liver function

title: Impedance
detail:
• Obstruction or opposition to passage or flow, as of an electric current or other form of energy
• Used to test blood samples in an instrument that passes a current of light or electricity through the sample (e.g. electronic cell counters that use impedance to classify cells based on their size)

title: Iohexol clearance test
detail:
• Used to estimate GFR (Glomerular Filtration Rate) in dogs and cats
• Iohexol is a radiographic agent that is administered IV after a 12-hour fast w access to water
• Serum samples are taken at 2, 3, 4 hours

title: Urine sample collection
detail:
• Voided samples contain bacteria (not suitable for bacteriologic exam) and often WBCs; midstream sample is preferred
• Bladder expression samples are not suitable for bacteriologic culturing; RBCs possible due to pressure
• Catheterization is the preferred method to assess patency of the urethra—if urethra is not patent, urinary catheter won’t pass; can also be used to obtain sample for bacterial culture
• Cystocentesis is the preferred method for obtaining a urine sample for bacterial culture; gets sterile samples

title: Blood samples from anemic patients
detail: • Increase the pusher slide angle to about 45 degrees—anemic blood is thinner in consistency and using the normal angle creates too long a smear (increasing the angle shortens the smear)

title: Bordetella bronchiseptica
detail: • Bacterial infection that is most commonly associated w infectious tracheobronchitis (kennel cough) in dogs

title: Unique characteristic of Mycobacterium
detail:
• Survives phagocytosis
• Require special staining (along w Nocardia) bc they are acid-fast bacteria w waxy cell walls caused by mycolic acid and wax, fatty acid, and lipid mixture that makes them not pick up standard stains
• Must also be heat-fixed
• Zoonotic

title: Coggins test
detail: • Blood test that determines if a horse is a carrier of Equine Infectious Anemia (viral disease)

title: Fresh frozen plasma
detail:
• Liquid part of donated blood
• Rich in clotting factors and proteins
• Used to treat severe bleeding or clotting disorders
• Administered IV as a blood transfusion
• Frozen w/in 8 hours of donation to preserve coagulation factors
• Retains coagulation factor efficacy for 12 months, then it has to be relabeled frozen plasma (lower clotting factor levels)

title: Worms
detail:
• Spirocerca lupi: Esophageal worm; nematode that forms nodules in the esophagus
• Physaloptera: Canine stomach worm
• Filaroides: Canine lungworm
• Metastrongylus: Lungworm

title: Prothrombin time test
detail:
• One-stage test for detecting certain plasma coagulation defects caused by a deficiency of factors V, VII, X
• Used to confirm a diagnosis of warfarin toxicity—it leads to prolonged clotting times and affects factors II, VII, IX, and X

title: Magnification for blood smears
detail:
• Platelets are the smallest elements found in a peripheral blood smear so higher magnification is necessary to view them adequately (e.g. to estimate platelet numbers)
• 10× objective lenses should be used to scan the feathered edge for rouleaux, RBC agglutination, and platelet clumping

title: Smear preparation for cytology samples
detail:
• For solid masses:
• Compression preparation (aka squash prep): Aspirate is expelled onto the slide, a second slide is placed perpendicular to form + shape, and slid across—best technique
• Combination technique: Same as above but w 45° angle
• Starfish smear: Aspirate is dragged w a needle
• For fluid samples: Best done immediately and w EDTA
• Line smear: When concentration w centrifugation isn’t an option or sample has low cellularity blood smear technique is used

title: Bicarbonate
detail:
• Electrolyte in plasma
• Primary function is maintaining blood pH through acid–base buffering

title: Glucose tolerance test
detail:
• Directly challenge the pancreas w a glucose load, and measure insulin's effect by evaluating blood or urine glucose concentration
• Prolonged hyperglycemia and glucosuria are consistent w DM
• Healthy animals have sufficient insulin to drop the increased glucose load to normal levels in 2 hours; animals w DM typically show hyperglycemia and glucosuria in the same period

title: Myasthenia gravis
detail:
• Autoimmune disorder; immune system attacks acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, blocking nerve signals to muscles and causing weakness
• Results in the esophageal muscle losing its normal tone (megaesophagus)
• Often leads to death due to aspiration pneumonia when animal breathes in some of the frequently regurgitated food
• Also causes exercise-related generalized muscle weakness that improves with rest

title: -ologies
detail:
• Serology is the study of antibody–antigen reactions
• Parasitology is the study of endoparasites and ectoparasites
• Microbiology is the study of viruses or prions
• Mycology is the study of fungi

title: Hypothyroidism screening
detail: • Thyroid hormone controls synthesis and destruction of cholesterol, so cholesterol levels are elevated in animals w hypothyroidism

title: Primary vs. secondary hemostasis
detail:
• Primary hemostasis: Platelet plug formation
• Evaluated by buccal mucosal bleeding time; detects abnormalities in platelet function
• Secondary hemostasis: Formation of fibrin by coagulation factors
• Evaluated by ACT, APPT, and one-step PT
• Usually initiated simultaneously
• Activated platelets promote fibrin formation and provide a physical scaffold on which fibrin formation proceeds
• Thrombin generated by secondary hemostasis is a platelet agonist and also induces endothelial cells to release vWf

title: Phagocytosis
detail:
• Innate immune process in which activated phagocytes migrate toward, bind, ingest, and destroy pathogens
• Primary phagocytes are neutrophils and monocytes / macrophages
• Stages of phagocytosis: Activation → Chemotaxis → Adherence → Ingestion → Destruction
• Chemotaxis is moving towards the target
• Opsonization is the process by which pathogens are coated w molecules (opsonins such as antibodies) that make them easier for phagocytes to recognize and ingest; occurs during adherence

title: Findings for urine specimen collected free catch and left at room temperature
detail:
• Decreased glucose and bilirubin concentrations
• Increased pH resulting from bacterial breakdown of urea to ammonia
• Crystal formation w increased sample turbidity
• Breakdown of casts and RBCs (especially in dilute or alkaline urine)
• Bacterial proliferation leading to increased numbers of bacteria

title: Common problems for blood chemistry samples
detail: • Common interferences in clinical chemistries include bilirubin, hemolysis, and lipemia

title: Measuring electrolytes
detail:
• Electrochemical and ion-specific methods are used most often
• IDEXX VetLyte uses ion-specific electrodes to measure sodium, potassium, and chloride

title: Fimbriae
detail:
• Hair-like appendages (aka common pili) on the surface of bacteria, particularly Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli
• Bind bacteria to cell surfaces, allowing bacteria to attach to mucosal surfaces, colonize tissues, and form biofilms

title: Lentivirus
detail:
• Genus of retroviruses characterized by slow, progressive disease with a long incubation period
• Cause chronic, lifelong infections
• Include
• Equine lentiviruses (e.g. Equine infectious anemia virus)
• Feline lentiviruses (e.g. Feline immunodeficiency virus)

title: Mucin clot test
detail:
• Test performed w joint fluid
• Synovial fluid mucin forms a clot when added to acetic acid, which reflects the quality and concentration of hyaluronic acid

title: Anaplasma
detail:
• Diagnosed by examining blood sample—blood films made from buffy coat may aid in diagnosis, but immunologic testing better as organisms may not be seen
• Disease may result in neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and anemia
• Chronically affected animals may be severely anemic, w marked leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, but sometimes the only hematologic abnormality is lymphocytosis
• Total plasma protein level is usually increased

title: Dioctophyma renale
detail:
• Giant kidney worm
• Inhabits the walls of portions of the urinary system of both dogs and cats
• Diagnosed by microscopic examination of urine

title: Testing for suspected acetaminophen ingestion
detail:
• Plasma (from EDTA or heparin-preserved blood) or serum and urine are the preferred antemortem samples
• Blood concentrations usually peak 4 to 6 hours after ingestion
• Samples should be refrigerated if analyzed w/in 24 hours, otherwise be frozen
• Blood smear should be examined for Heinz bodies

title: Xylitol toxicity
detail:
• Artificial sweetener
• Extremely toxic to dogs
• Causes hyperphosphatemia or hypophosphatemia

title: Pancytopenia
detail:
• Decrease in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets
• Most commonly caused by bone marrow suppression

title: Supernatant
detail: • Clear liquid that remains on top of a mixture after solid particles have settled or been centrifuged

title: Signs of calibration and/or quality control problems in equipment
detail:
• Flags on printed results on several values
• Values not compatible w life
• Hematocrit (HCT) that is 5 times the hemoglobin concentration
• Another abnormal result or relationship bw 2 parameters

title: Campylobacter spp. (campy)
detail:
• Gram-negative spirochete
• Appears as two curved rods joined end to end; similar to a seagull
• May not be visible on gram stain and need a culture
• Zoonotic

title: Cornified cells
detail:
• Keratinized cells w no blood supply
• Indicates estrus if found on canine vaginal smear
• Cornification begins forming a protective lining w/in the vagina during proestrus; epithelial cells continue to cornify during estrus, and shed during metestrus

title: Limitations of lab equipment
detail:
• Species specificity
• Susceptibility to inferences (e.g. microclots leading to lower platelet count)
• Ability to distinguish between cell types

title: Refractometers
detail: • Used to measure urine specific gravity and plasma/serum protein concentration

title: Timeline for bacterial culture plates
detail: • No growth after 3 days indicates a negative result since bacteria should be visible on inoculated plates w/in 24 to 48 hours

title: Controls
detail:
• Used to monitor a test’s performance and make sure it runs correctly
• Should be used daily before running patient samples
• Commercially available; normal-abnormal or low-normal-high depeding on equipment
